articles.title: Endings are hard, but facing them helps us to heal
articles.trailText: I understand the temptation to run away – I have felt it too. Try to stay in the room, and in the moment. You’ll be glad you did
articles.summary: Moya Sarner’s final How to build a better life column reflects on the healing power of endings, urging readers to stay present rather than avoid difficult farewells. She argues that therapy endings offer a vital space for mourning unmet needs and confronting abandonment, and recounts her own experience when her father died while her infant daughter slept beside him in a hospice courtyard. Confronting his death—prompted by a psychoanalyst’s truth—allowed intimate moments of grief, gratitude and growth. Sarner champions psychodynamic psychotherapy in the NHS as a way to ‘stay in the room’, face endings and truly live.

articles.title: ‘Oysters are a risk, as is raw meat’: why you get food poisoning – and how to avoid it
articles.trailText: Several kinds of bacteria can give you an upset stomach. Here is how to steer clear of the worst offenders, and what to do if they do make it through
articles.summary: Food poisoning occurs when you ingest food contaminated with bacteria or toxins. Some pathogens (eg Bacillus cereus in reheated rice) produce toxins pre-ingestion, causing rapid vomiting; others (Salmonella, E coli, Campylobacter) trigger gut inflammation and diarrhoea later. Antibiotics are rarely prescribed without exact diagnosis, as they can worsen toxin-mediated illness. To prevent infection, avoid raw oysters and undercooked meat, sear all exposed beef, never wash chicken, refrigerate cooked food within two hours, use separate utensils, a meat thermometer and wash hands thoroughly. If ill, prioritise rehydration with oral salts and a BRAT diet; seek medical help for severe dehydration, sepsis signs or lingering symptoms like IBS.

articles.title: The one change that worked: sharing ‘accountability’ notes has made life better for both of us
articles.trailText: Would telling a buddy my to-do list was done – before I’d done it – really make it more likely to happen? But leaving her a voice note every day has increased my productivity, and deepened our friendship
articles.summary: Brooklyn-based journalist and her London friend Rosamund send each other daily two-minute voice notes describing tasks in the past tense—“I wrote my feature,” “I took a walk”—to create accountability, manifest goals and boost productivity. Over six months, this pact replaced rigid to-do lists, helping them follow through on complex work, exercise and family outings. A side benefit: regaining intimacy through mundane micro-news—from new cafés to pirate-themed parties—reconnecting them across time zones and enriching both their productivity and friendship.

articles.title: Is it true that … wearing heels changes the shape of your feet?
articles.trailText: Stilettos are fine for an evening out, but wearing them all day, every day could cause permanent damage
articles.summary: Consultant orthopaedic foot specialist Andrew Goldberg reversed his view after 3D scans showing high heels crowd toes, cause bunions and clawing. Regular all-day heel wear stretches soft tissue, narrows the forefoot and leads to bunions, hammer toes and arthritis over years. Even everyday shoes influence foot shape, especially tight or pointed styles. Many wear footwear that’s too small. Goldberg advises daily foot exercises – toe grips or brief barefoot tiptoe walks – and moderation: heels for occasional events, not eight hours every day.

articles.title: ‘I am not happy with my output!’ Kate Hudson on taking risks, rejecting compromise – and finding her voice at 46
articles.trailText: After years as Hollywood’s romcom darling, Hudson is putting music at the centre of her career – and after her show-stealing turn in Song Sung Blue, the Oscar buzz is growing
articles.summary: At 46, Kate Hudson rejects safe rom-coms to center music in her career, earning Golden Globe and Oscar buzz for Song Sung Blue, where she plays Claire “Thunder” Sardina, a Neil Diamond tribute singer alongside Hugh Jackman. From her breakthrough as Penny Lane in Almost Famous through hits like How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days, overlooked dramas and misfires, Hudson draws on lifelong musical roots and a recent ADHD diagnosis as she embraces risk, vowing “I want to fail more” for authentic output. She co-hosts podcast Sibling Revelry, balances three children, and champions women’s creative agency over compromise.

articles.title: Burning questions on scented candles | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Hosting advice | George Osborne’s expertise | Stolen museum artefacts | Stages of ageing | US travel or letter published?
articles.summary: Published 14 December 2025, the Brief letters page features Carol Dunnett’s scepticism about The Filter’s tip to burn low-scent candles for two hours in a downstairs loo before entertaining; Austen Lynch’s quip comparing George Osborne’s 'austerity expert' tag to Dickens’s Artful Dodger; Clive Collins’s noting that Bristol Museum artefacts were historically looted; Jonathan Hauxwell and Matthew Ryder’s tongue-in-cheek stages of ageing via heritage memberships and letter-writing; Mark de Brunner’s preference for Guardian publication over US travel authorization; and an open call for reader submissions, reminding readers to email their views on any Guardian content.

articles.title: Dog play afternoon: dachshunds overrun Hyde Park for Christmas walk
articles.trailText: Hundreds of sausage dogs gather for annual festive parade that organiser started to help her puppy socialise
articles.summary: Hundreds of dachshunds and owners converged at Hyde Park’s Physical Energy statue for the eighth annual sausage dog Christmas walk, founded by Ana Rodriguez to socialize her puppy Winston. Participants donned festive costumes—gifts, reindeer, tinsel—and competed in a best-dressed contest before a one-hour play session and parade. Debutant Koda arrived with spare rain gear, while long‐time attendees praised the breed’s loyalty and humanlike bonds. Originating as German hunting dogs, dachshunds now see soaring UK registrations and are encouraged to take daily exercise. On Sunday, their only quarry was treats amid joyful chaos.

articles.title: The kindness of strangers: I was so ill I couldn’t walk when a man virtually carried me to the toilets
articles.trailText: I was determined not to vomit in front of six lanes of traffic, so I started crawling towards a nearby park
articles.summary: When she was 19, a commuter on a crowded express bus, she felt violently nauseous and asked the driver to stop as her vision faded. Exiting onto a busy street with six lanes of traffic, she tried to crawl toward a park but blacked out. A passing stranger lifted her in his arms, carried her into a nearby building’s ladies’ toilets and remained outside checking on her until she recovered. Treated for a stomach bug days later, she never saw his face but reflects on how spontaneous compassion reaffirms human kindness.

articles.title: Joely Richardson looks back: ‘Natasha’s death was life-changing. She was a figurehead to me’
articles.trailText: The Nip/Tuck and Downton Abbey star on losing her sister, growing up in a theatrical dynasty, and how she feels about ageing
articles.summary: Joely Richardson, 60, veteran actor and campaigner born to Vanessa Redgrave and Tony Richardson, rose from modest, theatrical roots to breakout roles in 101 Dalmatians, Nip/Tuck and Downton Abbey. Self-described shy tomboy, she channeled teenage rebellion into school plays and later seized an “It-girl” moment at a 2000 premiere. After sister Natasha’s 2009 death, Richardson’s life pivoted, supporting her nephews and redefining purpose. Now working with Save the Children’s Christmas Jumper Day, she embraces ageing—finding freedom after 50—while navigating limited roles for older women, especially in the UK. Reflecting on past struggles, she celebrates resilience, urging her younger self that inner strength prevails despite heartbreak.

articles.title: Readers reply: why are we not better people?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions takes a quizzical look at human nature. Why hasn’t it advanced along with other forms of progress? Or has it?
articles.summary: Over decades, readers tackle John Gorrill’s dilemma: why hasn’t moral nature evolved alongside brain, healthcare and tech? Contributors cite capitalism and reward systems that favour performative or selfish over altruistic conduct; evolutionary stable strategies balancing hawks and doves; innate primate instincts documented by Jane Goodall; scarcity, patriarchy, media focus on bad actors; philosophical (Aristotle, Russell) and theological frameworks urging supernatural standards. While ethics have widened moral circles, systemic pressures—inequality, in-groups, fear—persist. Responses span eras from Aristotle’s Nichomachean Ethics to Russell’s Has Man a Future?, questioning if evolution alone can nurture cooperation. Consensus holds that progress demands deliberate structural, economic and cultural reform.

articles.title: What is – or was – the best-ever internet meme?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: Guardian’s Life & Style series asks readers to nominate the all-time greatest internet meme: choices range from the dramatic chipmunk and distracted boyfriend to the candy-floss raccoon and Success Kid. Contributors can post answers in the comments or email them; a curated selection will appear next Sunday. This reader-driven feature explores meme culture, fan favorites and viral phenomena, inviting community debate on enduring digital humor and cultural impact.

articles.title: Dining across the divide: ‘We discussed whether we should increase immigration, and I said no’
articles.trailText: An author and a tech coach had a heated debate about refugees, loud phones in public spaces, and our reliance on cars. Did they part with a smile?
articles.summary: Louisa, a 39-year-old author and comms professional who wrote a book on digital minimalism, and Andy, a 62-year-old agile tech coach and new musician (MeMe), shared truffle-infused pasta and seafood spaghetti at Citro, London N6. They agreed Brexit hurt both but clashed on immigration—Andy opposing increases over mismanagement versus Louisa’s refugee family history—on loud phone use (fines vs polite request), and on car reliance (better transport vs personal responsibility). They parted smiling, underscoring the value of respectful, open-minded debate.

articles.title: Dim the lights, add a trinket tray and put out your best towels: how to spruce up your spare room
articles.trailText: Impress your guests with interiors experts’ top tips for a stylish sleepover
articles.summary: Hosts are urged to test-drive their spare room by sleeping in it, then declutter and deep-clean surfaces. Add personality with greenery or vintage accents and boutique-style textures. Outfit the bed with fresh linens, cosy throws and blackout options or sleep masks. Provide bedside lamps, easy-access chargers, a water carafe and glasses, plus a trinket tray and waste bin. Include a vanity mirror, hairdryer, clothes hooks or rail, cosmetic containers, hot-water bottles and a subtle diffuser or candle. After guests depart, transform the space into a personal reading nook or retreat. These touches ensure a functional, stylish and welcoming guest stay.

articles.title: ‘The adventure can turn into a disaster’: the digital nomad families ‘worldschooling’ their children
articles.trailText: Forget homeschooling, how about taking your family on a perpetual gap year and quitting the nine-to-five? Families who did just that share the hostel horrors and mid-trip meltdowns behind the Instagram feed
articles.summary: Three families quit jobs to ‘worldschool’ children: Davises sold home to travel Oman, Sri Lanka, Malaysia and Thailand but returned early after a family tragedy and their daughters’ homesickness; Wiringis have roamed since 2020 with four kids on tourist visas, mixing self-directed lessons with informal, slow travel; Wards fund blog income, swap labour for lodging and balance textbooks with museum visits but endured illness and visa hurdles. Worldschoolers laud flexibility, real-world learning and resilience yet warn of loneliness, homeschooling stress and disrupted routines.

articles.title: My dad has given my brother 80% of his business and I feel horribly dismissed
articles.trailText: You’re reluctant to discuss this with your parents – but doing so might help you shake off the feeling of injustice
articles.summary: A doctor writes in hurt after her father granted her brother 80% of his multimillion-pound business, enabling him to retire early, while she received only university and housing support and a future inheritance of the family home and residual estate. She struggles with mortgage costs and feels dismissed and second-rate despite her hard work and caregiving. UKCP-registered therapist Michelle Briggs observes that money may mask deeper emotional neglect, and urges the reader to reframe self-worth, open a candid dialogue with her parents – focusing on feelings rather than money – and clarify what relationship repair might look like.

articles.title: ‘You just feel so light!’: two wheelchair users – one 81, one 25 – on welfare cuts, housing and the joy of swimming
articles.trailText: Technology has improved since the 50s and in the last five or six years especially, there has been a lot of progress. But the world is still too often designed without wheelchair users in mind
articles.summary: Alice Moira, 81, and Lochlann O’Higgins, 25, compare decades of change for UK wheelchair users: from wooden chairs and inaccessible schools to self-propelled frames, Motability cars and wheelchair-friendly university halls. Both praise tech advances—apps mapping step-free routes, sports chairs—and the joy of swimming, rugby and community, but warn of persistent design barriers in housing, transport and workplaces. They urge government to protect Personal Independence Payments amid benefit cuts and call for equal opportunities to try new activities. Thirty years after the Disability Discrimination Act, they celebrate progress yet stress ongoing struggles for true accessibility.

articles.title: The moment I knew: as he opened the Uber door, he opened my eyes to a love beyond work
articles.trailText: Ash Jacks McCready had low expectations for her first date with Tom, but after an awkward start, their relationship moved fast and wild
articles.summary: After losing her job as a Cirque du Soleil assistant creative director when the pandemic struck, former dancer Ash Jacks McCready returned to her parents’ home in Noosa and tried online dating. She reconnected with high-school crush Tom, initially cancelling three invitations before accepting the fourth. When he unexpectedly opened the Uber door for her, she felt a rare kindness and realized she’d been closing herself off. Their whirlwind romance included weekend visits, cohabitation, and two children. With Tom’s support she declined a Cirque offer, produced her own show while pregnant and now debuts as creative director of Cirque Alice.

articles.title: ‘My photos are warm and full of imagination – that’s something AI could never achieve’: Yuan Li’s best phone picture
articles.trailText: This spectacular image taken in Sakrisøy, Norway, triggered accusations that it was simply too good to be true
articles.summary: Beijing-based photographer and ski instructor Yuan Li snapped this vivid image of a yellow coastal homestay against Olstinden mountain while touring Norway’s Lofoten islands on a winter–summer trip chasing the aurora. Splitting his time between ski instructing in winter and photography in summer, he captured this phone shot after a heavy snowfall cleared and later enhanced the color, its warm foreground contrasting cool peaks with triangular eaves mirroring the summit. Despite AI claims, Li argues no algorithm can match his warmth and imagination.

articles.title: Dorothy Parker ‘fwowed up’ in a 1928 review of which children’s classic? The Saturday quiz
articles.trailText: From demon, equal and encyclopedia to The Tour of Life and Before the Dawn, test your knowledge with the Saturday quiz
articles.summary: This Saturday quiz tests your wide-ranging trivia: from film and numismatics to literature and natural history. Questions cover the inflation-adjusted highest-grossing film (Gone With the Wind), multiple revamps of British coinage, Dorothy Parker’s 1928 critique of The House at Pooh Corner, the Andean condor, Harris Tweed’s orb mark, the Almanach de Gotha directory of European nobility, Vienna’s Prater park and the Northern soul scene. Themed link challenges include Wimbledon finalists vs Björn Borg, UK patron saints’ deaths, composers’ ninth symphony nicknames, sitcom character origins, erstwhile ae ligatures, Kate Bush tours and famous Louvre art thefts.

articles.title: Why do moths eat clothes and how old is the universe? The kids’ quiz
articles.trailText: Five multiple-choice questions – set by children – to test your knowledge, and a chance to submit your own junior brainteasers for future quizzes ​
articles.summary: This quiz rounds up five child-written multiple-choice questions on everyday science—from why moths nibble natural fibers to estimating the universe’s age—and challenges adults to test their knowledge while showcasing kids’ curiosity. Hosted by Molly Oldfield on the Everything Under the Sun podcast, it also prompts readers to submit their own junior brainteasers for future editions. The feature highlights Oldfield’s books: Everything Under the Sun, its Quiz Book spinoff and the All Around the World volume for hands-on learning.

articles.title: Blind date: ‘He’s a cat lover and I’m allergic. I would hate to make him have to choose!’
articles.trailText: Rita, 35, a travel agent, meets Tom, 40, a social media manager
articles.summary: Rita (35, travel agent) and Tom (40, social media manager) met via The Guardian’s blind-date series and dined at The Palomar, London. They bonded over food, UK travel, Alan Partridge and parents’ meeting stories. Awkward tube barrier hug and booking mix-up aside, they praised each other’s table manners and warmth. They had dessert, a pub drink but no kiss, both scoring the date 7/10. Shared interests fizzled over a key mismatch: Tom’s cats vs. Rita’s allergy, so neither will meet again.

articles.title: Tim Dowling: my band is set to play live on the radio. What could possibly go wrong?
articles.trailText: Rehearsals for a live broadcast at short notice reduce us to silence then swearing. This does not bode well
articles.summary: Tim Dowling’s band is thrust into a live national radio slot at 72 hours’ notice with only four members. Tasked to reinterpret cricket chants on Beach Boys melodies like “Sloop John B,” they endure frantic rehearsals at the fiddle player’s house – tweaking intros, endings and harmonies through arguments and six takes just to send the drummer a demo. On Saturday they X-ray instruments at Broadcasting House, brace themselves behind four mics, survive two numbers under Patrick Kielty’s interview, then leave shaken yet relieved.

articles.title: Has Simon Cowell lost his mojo? Seven things you need to know about the music mogul’s new direction
articles.trailText: The former X Factor judge is back, auditioning boyband wannabes for his latest talent show – but gen Z doesn’t seem to care very much, or even know who he is
articles.summary: Simon Cowell returns in Netflix docuseries The Next Act, hunting a new boyband despite Gen Z’s indifference. Critics call the open-call audition format and radio-centric promotion anachronistic amid TikTok-driven hits. Cowell reluctantly engages influencers, confronts low name recognition, and glosses over the mental-health toll on past stars like the late Liam Payne. At home in LA he remains exacting—prizing calorie restriction, Botox and strict routines—while balancing fiancée Lauren Silverman’s diplomacy. Ultimately, Cowell’s latest venture reaffirms his ambition to reclaim pop’s spotlight, even as culture moves on.

articles.title: Myf Warhurst: ‘I felt a bit lost. I’ve been too scared for too long’
articles.trailText: The longtime presenter discusses the ‘brutal’ radio culture of the 90s, the shedding of inner-city life, and why ‘now is the time to push myself’
articles.summary: Myf Warhurst reflects on her journey from country childhood to pioneering roles on Triple J and Spicks and Specks, navigating 'brutal' 90s radio sexism and blokey TV panels. After years anchoring others’ projects, she now drives her own podcasts—Double J's Bang On and The Moment—embracing creative freedom in her riverside Warrandyte home. She describes unlearning ingrained expectations, pushing beyond fear, and finding balance between culture and calm by the Yarra. With voice work on Bluey and ABC specials, Warhurst feels reborn: “Now is the time to push myself.”

articles.title: Digested week: Rejoice! A new oven is here before Christmas. Just a pity I can’t cook | Lucy Mangan
articles.trailText: My offer to host dinner is declined. My cooking is never good. Triumph lies in the fact food is cooked and not full of bacteria
articles.summary: At week’s start Mangan rails against the 'fetishisation' of fancy festive sandwiches—especially Harrods’s £29 steakhouse version—and insists cold, one-handed rolls aren’t proper food. She next rejoices in her family’s long-awaited new oven—finally cooking roast chicken, gammon and boulangère potatoes without bacterial horror, even if her clan won’t risk her for Christmas dinner. She mocks RSPCA research on stressed reindeer mascots, applauds Sheringham’s sit-in that saved a 1950s muralled bus shelter, and dives into Christmas shopping and post-sale ambitions for the ultimate pillow, heated throw, ideal jacket and 800 books.

articles.title: Festive stress getting to you? A potter in the garden is the ideal antidote
articles.trailText: Escape from the Christmas mayhem to spruce up pots and outdoor furniture, sow sweet peas, or even paint a fence
articles.summary: With Christmas just days away and festive pressure mounting, the author suggests escaping the chaos by lightly pottering in the garden—tidying pots, composting spent annuals, clearing leaves and stray tools—to restore calm and space for reflection. Tasks range from painting a fence or freshening up outdoor furniture during Twixmas to sowing sweet peas in a cold frame on Boxing Day, pruning roses or cleaning tools. The ritual of winter gardening complements an indoor “winter clean,” donating unused items and clearing space, offering mindfulness, fresh air and a sense of order before the busy new year, capped off with a comforting cup of tea.

articles.title: Experience: I stopped a man from crashing our plane
articles.trailText: A passenger having a mental health episode was heading for the emergency exit. He lunged for the door handle, screaming
articles.summary: In September 2024, a bestselling historical thriller author returning from a literary festival in Italy found himself on a Ryanair flight to London Stansted when a powerfully built passenger, in the midst of a mental health crisis, lunged for the emergency exit during descent. Fearing sudden depressurisation and loss of control, the author and two fellow travellers tackled and restrained the man until he calmed down and crew secured the cabin. The flight circled before landing safely; police arrested the passenger, now on a no-fly list. The writer, unhurt, felt both sympathy for the man’s panic attack and frustration at Ryanair’s silence after their lifesaving intervention.

articles.title: Teenagers are presenting Christmas wishlists, Powerpoint-style – my daughter included
articles.trailText: A far cry from hand scrawled letters to Santa, on graphic design platform Canva users have created a whopping 1.4m Christmas wishlist presentations
articles.summary: Since 2019, Canva’s Christmas wishlist templates have become a teenage craze: 3.35m designs created, with a 61% rise in presentation-style lists (1.4m) between 2024 and 2025. Teens—mostly girls in late tweens—assemble “aesthetic” slideshows with brand collages, categorized gift slides (clothes, beauty, decor, books), prices, mood boards, and occasional “dupe” options; some even embed hyperlinks. Parents report mixed feelings: efficient, clear wishlists but lacking the charm of glitter-smeared letters. Despite nostalgia for handwritten notes, many appreciate the thought and effort behind these polished pitches. The trend highlights a shift in holiday traditions, blending office-mode efficiency with festive cheer.

articles.title: Tell us: how important are your pets during Christmas?
articles.trailText: We’d like to know more about your how much your pets feature in your life during the festive period
articles.summary: An invitation to readers to share how pivotal pets are in their Christmas celebrations, exploring whether they allocate more of their holiday budget to pet gifts than to family and friends, opt out of seasonal gatherings to stay with their animal companions, and how these choices reflect the emotional role pets play during the festive period. The article seeks personal anecdotes about spending priorities, social sacrifices, and festive rituals centred around dogs, cats or other pets, aiming to map the varied ways animals influence holiday traditions and family dynamics.

articles.title: You be the judge: should my wannabe influencer friend stop using me for content?
articles.trailText: Marielle says being recorded is part of being her friend, but Beth is fed up of being a muse. Who should reel it in?
articles.summary: Beth, whose friend Marielle calls herself a “content queen,” says she’s tired of being filmed mid-bite for Marielle’s Instagram vlogs—enduring cold food, secondhand embarrassment and unpaid filming duties—despite asking Marielle to stop. Marielle argues casual video shoots are central to her creative identity and career goals, touting spontaneity, industry perks and willingness to delete unwanted clips. Reader jurors urge clear boundaries on consent and privacy, recommend Marielle recruit other collaborators, agree on approved moments and preserve genuine friendship over constant documentation. An online poll on over-exposure closes 17 December.

articles.title: Thursday news quiz: wildlife mystique, a museum leak, and Liz Truss speaks
articles.trailText: Test yourself on topical news trivia, pop culture and general knowledge every Thursday. How will you fare?
articles.summary: Guardian’s Thursday Quiz No 227 invites readers to tackle topical trivia on wildlife mystique, a museum ceiling leak and Liz Truss’s recent remarks. The weekly mix of pop culture and general knowledge offers only bragging rights (and Willow the quiz dog’s judging side-eye). Players are urged to post evidence-backed challenges in comments if they spot factual slip-ups, though it’s all in good fun. No prizes are awarded, but smug satisfaction awaits correct answers—and there’s a playful nod to Sia’s festive track ‘Sunshine’ as a quiz-time soundtrack.

articles.title: Rudolph at the Christmas market: cute festive attraction or damaging reindeer’s health?
articles.trailText: Keeping reindeer in pens for public enjoyment can cause them physical and mental harm, charities warn
articles.summary: Animal charities warn that reindeer hired to appear in UK Christmas markets, shopping centres and events—often for £400 stints of two to eight hours—suffer weight loss, muscle atrophy, fatigue and distress due to long-distance travel, warm environments and constant public interaction. A joint letter from 22 groups, including the RSPCA and World Animal Protection, cites a study showing 75% display physical or mental illness and urges abandoning festive reindeer displays in favour of herd-focused, climate-appropriate care. Experts emphasize need for specialist Arctic conditions and space to roam. 153 events have already switched to animal-free entertainment since 2018.

articles.title: My petty gripe: why do we have to review everything now? | Ellen Smith
articles.trailText: I don’t really believe that companies would love my feedback, nor that my opinion matters to them. So why do they keep asking for them?
articles.summary: Ellen Smith rails against review fatigue as companies bombard her inbox after every minor transaction—buying shoes, collecting parcels or calling her super fund—with requests for feedback. She questions whether anyone truly cares about her opinion and criticises the ubiquity of solicited reviews, arguing that most are pointless. While she concedes that genuine reviews can guide travel—such as finding decent coffee and avoiding grim caravan parks—she refuses to rate trivial items or professionals. Ultimately, Smith calls for relief from relentless feedback solicitations that clutter her email and add no real value.

articles.title: How neurodivergent households design ‘a home that knows your brain’
articles.trailText: From dark, sound-proofed rooms to clever storage solutions, families with autism and ADHD are finding inspired ways to adjust their environments
articles.summary: Melbourne designer Cherie Clonan reconfigured her weatherboard cottage around her autistic son and ADHD-diagnosed family members using the Dunn Model of Sensory Processing. She created distinct zones—a light-filled open plan for sensory seekers and a pitch-black, sound-proofed retreat for sensory avoiders—to balance stimulation and calm. Newcastle architect Eddie Page built a 16m² J-Pod studio for Josie with hoop pine panelling, hidden storage, block-out blinds and tuned climate control to cut clutter and overload. Psychologists agree that clear zones, visible organisation and tailored affordances ease daily tasks, boost focus and support neurodivergent wellbeing.

articles.title: The Christmas vibe shift: forget beige – the Home Alone look is all the rage
articles.trailText: This season calls for a tartan bow the size of a dinner plate, traditional baubles on the tree and a host of wooden nutcracker soldiers. ‘Ralph Lauren Christmas’ has gone viral, and gen Z has fallen hard for nostalgia and the 1990s
articles.summary: This season’s Christmas décor has pivoted from minimalist beige to a nostalgic “Home Alone” aesthetic: think oversized tartan bows, traditional baubles, wooden nutcrackers and cedar-draped staircases. Dubbed “Ralph Lauren Christmas” on TikTok (5 million searches), Gen Z is driving a retro ’90s revival—velvet ribbons, candy-cane striped ornaments and roaring fires—recreated on a budget. Brands from Burberry’s Claridge’s tree to John Lewis’s ’90s dancefloor ad echo this unashamedly jolly, abundant style. The trend channels family, warmth and earnest festivity over hygge minimalism, proving that this year, maximum nostalgia is the must-have look.

articles.title: A moment that changed me: my train crashed – and then I heard a little girl crying
articles.trailText: I waited for the carriage to roll over and burst into flames, but the sound of a child brought me out of my trance, and showed me how important it is to look outwards in a crisis
articles.summary: In her early 20s, Anna Woodford and her friend Helen were traveling by train from York to Blackburn when a runaway digger rolled into their carriage near Pudsey, derailing it. As they braced for disaster, the cry of a stranded seven-year-old girl jolted Anna into action: she comforted the child, handed her to firefighters, then escaped through a window ladder. No one was seriously hurt, but the ordeal solidified Anna’s 30-year friendship with Helen and imparted a lasting lesson in resilience, empathy and looking outwards in crisis.

articles.title: The art of going ‘Instagram official’: how 10 celebrity couples shared their love with the world
articles.trailText: Katy Perry and Justin Trudeau are the latest A-listers to announce their relationship status online. But there are many ways to do it - from fancy dress to panicked deletions
articles.summary: This article examines how ten celebrity couples have declared their relationships publicly on Instagram, illustrating varied tactics: from Katy Perry and Justin Trudeau’s direct grid reveal to Ariana Grande’s cryptic carousel with Ethan Slater; Selena Gomez’s brief Weeknd post then deletion; Channing Tatum and Zoë Kravitz in matching Halloween costumes; Elizabeth Hurley’s Easter smooch with Billy Ray Cyrus; Shakira and Piqué’s ex-retaliation; Bella Thorne’s classic eyeline pose; Zendaya and Tom Holland’s film-role wink; Chris Evans and Alba Baptista’s prank montage; Lana Del Rey’s mirror-kiss snapshot; and Taylor Swift’s high-profile backstage shot with Travis Kelce and royal guests.

articles.title: Alice Zaslavsky’s festive vegetable terrine – recipe
articles.trailText: Using store-bought deli goods, Alice Zaslavsky builds a vegetarian showstopper for the Christmas table – with minimal cooking
articles.summary: Alice Zaslavsky's make-ahead vegetarian terrine layers grilled zucchini, roasted eggplant, red capsicum and sundried tomatoes with a tangy artichoke-cream binder. Assembled in a loaf tin, it sets overnight, then is dressed with homemade basil-pine nut pesto, cherry tomato halves, basil leaves and lemon wedges. Uses store-bought deli goods to minimise cooking; grill zucchini if needed. Vegan swaps: nutritional yeast & cashew cheese. Travel-friendly—keep components separate and assemble on-site. Serves 6–8.

articles.title: Houseplant hacks: can grow lights help plants during winter?
articles.trailText: As the days grow shorter and darkness descends, tropical varieties can struggle. But there’s a clever fix that nature can’t provide
articles.summary: During winter’s shorter days and dimmer light, tropical houseplants often fade and slow growth from insufficient photosynthesis. Full-spectrum LED grow lights, priced £15–£100, supplement natural light when hung 20–30cm above plants. In well-lit spots use 3–4 hours daily; in darker corners increase to 6–8. Monitor leaves for bleaching (excess) or stretching (deficit). A clip-on LED restored a north-facing philodendron’s healthy, evenly spaced leaves within weeks. Overall, grow lights effectively balance light deficits in winter and are a worthwhile investment for serious indoor gardeners.

articles.title: ‘There’s no longer a heartbeat’: the couple whose twins were stillborn – and the ‘birth keeper’ they blame
articles.trailText: Soon-to-be parents hired a woman they believed would act as a licensed midwife. But she in fact belonged to a radical society that was linked to baby deaths around the world
articles.summary: Ernesta Chirwa and husband Chifundo Bingala in Cape Town engaged Caitlyn Collins believing her a licensed midwife, but she was trained by the US-based Free Birth Society (FBS) as a ‘radical birth keeper’. Collins provided no medical care, fell asleep during labour, drove them to an ill-equipped hospital, then abandoned them. At 43 weeks Chirwa delivered dying twins—a hidden twin pregnancy—prompting negligence claims as the couple sues Collins and exposes FBS’s dangerous anti-medical freebirth ideology.

articles.title: How to not spend a fortune during the holidays
articles.trailText: Budgeting advice, affordable gifts and more
articles.summary: Financial content creator Michela Allocca’s holiday spending guide emphasizes early savings, expense tracking and intentional gifting. Start a January holiday “sinking fund” or flash-save by cutting non-essentials, use cashback apps to build next year’s gift budget, and nix obligatory presents in favor of thoughtful items for close family. Explore budget-friendly gift lists—from under $10 stocking stuffers to $50 luxe finds—global and fashion gift guides, plus homemade options like sourdough or custom crafts to avoid overspending this season. Also check the one-stop shop of 163 Guardian-curated gifts across budgets and interests.

articles.title: Ticketek charged a $9 processing fee for my $35 ticket. Is this reasonable?
articles.trailText: Ticket-selling websites are free to set prices as they want, Australian policy expert Kat George writes. Buying direct from the box office is the best way around this
articles.summary: Ticketek’s $9 processing fee on a $35 AFL ticket, though frustrating, is legally allowable: under Australian Consumer Law and ACCC guidelines, ticket platforms may set service and handling charges to cover technology, staffing, resale and support. Credit-card surcharges must also be transparent but are separate. Drip pricing is banned—platforms must disclose the all-in ticket price at the outset. While Ticketek claims it clearly outlines fees throughout purchase, the only true way to avoid or reduce them is buying directly from a venue’s box office or gate, though risk of sell-outs for high-demand AFL matches remains.

articles.title: The one change that worked: I started bringing my own takeaway box to every meal – and sparked a mini movement
articles.trailText: Every year, 1bn tonnes of food are wasted. I value my meals and the work that has gone into them, so I am now always prepared and ready to take home delicious leftovers
articles.summary: After learning that 1.05 bn tonnes of food is wasted each year, the author adopted a reusable takeaway box at meals—starting at her birthday afternoon tea—to combat leftovers. Rooted in her vegetarian Gujarati Jain Kenyan-Indian upbringing, she overcame initial embarrassment, found staff accommodating and sparked curious conversations. Now she carries her box to restaurants, work events and overseas trips, saves money as a freelancer, and has inspired friends to join her burgeoning, grassroots anti–food-waste movement.

articles.title: Is it true that… you should take vitamin C when you’ve got a cold?
articles.trailText: The vitamin has many benefits, but research shows that people who take it are just as likely to get the sniffles as those who don’t
articles.summary: Imperial College’s Daniel M Davis explains that while vitamin C is a vital antioxidant protecting cells from toxins and aiding iron absorption and collagen synthesis, high-dose supplements or orange juice won’t prevent colds. Despite Linus Pauling’s 1970 bestseller igniting a 50-year myth, trials show supplement takers fall ill at similar rates, with only a modest 8% shorter symptom duration (likely skewed by healthier lifestyles). For robust immune health, prioritize vitamin D—via March–October sunlight or NHS-recommended winter supplements.

articles.title: A new start after 60: I moved on to a boat, fell in love – then opened my own restaurant
articles.trailText: After a lifetime of working for others, Rich Baker threw caution to the wind. The result was a national award for his pizza and a surprising surge in confidence
articles.summary: After decades in corporate hospitality, 60-year-old Rich Baker ditched full-time roles, moved onto a narrowboat and foraged English ingredients with partner Sarah. Starting from pop-ups in Hackney, they launched Flat Earth Pizzas in 2022, using heritage grains, seasonal produce and homemade kimchi. In 2023 his kimchi fiorentina won a national award, transforming the once-struggling venture into profitability, boosting his confidence and sense of fulfilment. Baker shows that reinvention after 60—driven by passion for local sourcing and bold risk-taking—can yield culinary success.

articles.title: Why are we not better people?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: John Gorrill of Cumberland poses the question: despite huge advances in brain capacity, knowledge, technology, healthcare and lifespan, why hasn’t human nature evolved morally at the same pace? Noting that every country across history has produced crime and warfare, he suggests we remain as morally primitive as our distant ancestors. This instalment of The Guardian’s long-running reader Q&A series invites further reader responses and fresh questions on the disconnect between our technological progress and ethical development, with selected contributions to be published next Sunday.

articles.title: The kindness of strangers: I couldn’t afford a pricey hotel, then a student let me sleep on her dormitory floor
articles.trailText: In retrospect, I can appreciate what a big chance she took. I hope the universe has repaid her many times over
articles.summary: In 2006, en route from Singapore to Canberra for an ANU medical school interview, the author found every budget hostel and backpacker lodge booked and the airport closed overnight. A passing ANU student spotted him, then offered her dormitory floor, a leftover stuffed baguette dinner, a hot shower and a safe place to sleep. Now a father, he reflects on her extraordinary trust, his own male privilege at the time, notes he never saw her again and hopes her kindness has been richly repaid.

articles.title: Anna Maxwell Martin looks back: ‘I was bullied a little bit, but it didn’t affect me because I was a happy weirdo’
articles.trailText: The actor on being an introverted extrovert, performing as a pearly queen, and becoming a single mother when her husband died
articles.summary: Actor Anna Maxwell Martin, born 1977 in Beverley, East Yorkshire, studied history at Liverpool and trained at LAMDA, winning a BAFTA for Bleak House. Known for Line of Duty, Motherland and stage roles, she became a single mother of two after director husband Roger Michell’s death in 2021. An introverted extrovert, she overcame childhood bullying, began performing as a pearly queen aged 10, and credits her 'happy weirdo' persona for driving her career. Now an Action for Children ambassador, she balances advocacy, motherhood and selective, respectful acting roles. She now prioritises roles with minimal commute, limited makeup time and positive sets, avoiding collaborators she deems 'dickheads'.

articles.title: Readers reply: What are the greatest life lessons?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: In this Guardian long-running series, readers share life lessons: release the need to fix or convert others and accept they change only when ready; cultivate deep satisfaction by making others happy yet prioritizing authenticity, laughter and supportive relationships; practice mindfulness—pause, listen, relinquish expectations, don’t sweat small stuff and remember ‘this too shall pass’; seek help when overwhelmed and approach unfamiliar spaces with confidence; embrace uncertainty, apply simple solutions (right duvet size, decluttering), adopt stoic principles from Marcus Aurelius; reject external gurus; and redefine womanhood beyond biological motherhood.

articles.title: Goodbye angels, hello Ozempic needles – what’s behind the boom in bizarre Christmas baubles?
articles.trailText: This year’s most-wanted ornaments include weight-loss syringes and favourite foodstuffs. When and why did Christmas trees become so commercialised?
articles.summary: Britons are transforming Christmas trees into personalised showcases of consumer culture, snapping up baubles shaped like Ozempic syringes, Botox vials, cocktails and favourite foods. The bestseller Ozempic bauble even sold out. Retailers from John Lewis—whose box-bauble sales fell 60% in a decade—to Selfridges (ornament sales +15%) mine sales data and secular trends (“wisdom” this year) to design themed collections. Growth in two-tree homes and gifting drives loose, quirky decorations. US wholesaler Cody Foster, Dutch maker Vondels and niche boutiques like Rockett St George compete with ironic, identity-driven novelties, echoing Victorian and Dickensian roots while pushing commercialised modern whimsy.

articles.title: Dining across the divide: ‘She’s not unwelcoming or racist but she thinks immigration is creating a brain drain elsewhere’
articles.trailText: They had different opinions on social media, asylum seekers and ‘woke’ politics, but which Stewart Lee sketch got them both laughing?
articles.summary: Samuel, 34, a London communications professional and recent Green party convert, and Catrina, 24, a former hospital homelessness caseworker and Green voter, met at Engel Bar for a German–Korean–seafood fusion meal. They sparred civilly over UK immigration—Catrina warned of ethical brain drain from West Africa while Samuel quoted a Stewart Lee anti-Ukip sketch—then found common ground on systemic racism vs individual ‘woke’ action. They capped the evening debating social media’s doom loops vs AI’s promise in cancer screening and swapped contacts for a follow-up.

articles.title: Roll with it: the 30 best board games for Christmas 2025
articles.trailText: If Monopoly is your festive fallback for family fun then go directly to Jail and do not pass Go. A new wave of party pleasers, trick takers and strategy games can transport you to Stalingrad, the spirit realm, or even Georgian sex venues
articles.summary: A seasoned board-game critic showcases 30 top titles to gift at Christmas 2025, charting the hobby’s renaissance beyond classics like Monopoly into modern Eurogames, trick-taking, deck-builders and thematic epics. Categorized by play style—party (Hot Streak, Wavelength), card (Scout, Courtisans), two-player (Splendor Duel, Watergate), light strategy (Joraku, Harmonies) and heavy (Undaunted: Stalingrad, Molly House)—this guide spans themes from medieval politics and cosmic conflict to cheesemaking and 18th-century queer London. Each pick suits different ages, group sizes and experience levels, promising fresh social fun and strategic depth for every gamer.

articles.title: The moment I knew: we were discussing Jane Austen when I told her I wanted to be with her for ever
articles.trailText: After meeting Miranda at a footy screening, Darcy Green found her a little terrifying. Months later, their feelings came pouring out
articles.summary: In 2018, Sydney native Darcy Green relocates to Oxford for a master’s, seeking family ties and iconic libraries, and meets Miranda—classical archaeology postgrad, rower and choir president—at a pre-dawn AFL Grand Final screening. Their rapport ignites over a pot-luck dinner where flaming Christmas pudding breaks the ice. Two months later, on a blustery Turl Street walk discussing Jane Austen’s romance, he blurts that he wants to be with her forever. They married in 2022 after long-distance challenges, a pandemic and sudden moves, and now live in Melbourne with two indoor rabbits.

articles.title: The truth about the ‘gender care gap’: are men really more likely to abandon their ill wives?
articles.trailText: It’s one thing facing a major diagnosis; it’s quite another dealing with your partner pulling away. But does the stereotype match the reality?
articles.summary: Article examines the stereotype that men are more likely to abandon partners when they fall ill. It opens with Jess’s experience of long Covid—cared for then dumped—then shares stories of couples facing brain injury, stroke and cancer. It reviews a 2009 US study and 2025 European data showing mixed patterns and notes research gaps and media bias. Interviews and expert views reveal hidden resentments, financial dependencies and silent caregiver grief. Ultimately it argues the 'gender care gap' is complex, shaped by emotional, social and economic factors rather than simple male desertion.

articles.title: ‘I climbed a building to get this shot of Egyptian fishermen with sardines’: Ahmad Mansour’s best phone picture
articles.trailText: How the photographer captured this split image of sardine fishermen taken from above
articles.summary: Freelance photographer Ahmad Mansour climbed a building in Alexandria’s Al Max fishing neighbourhood in 2019 to capture a split, top-down smartphone shot of sardine fishermen hauling nets under bright sun and reverberating calls. Inspired by earlier split-image work, he balanced shimmering water and silvery fish hues, proving vision outweighs gear. Mansour hopes viewers see a cinematic moment frozen in time. Since then, canal-side houses have been razed and the fishermen have relocated closer to the open sea.

articles.title: Fir real: expert tips on picking the perfect Christmas tree for the best price in the UK
articles.trailText: Millions of real trees are sold each year, and costs vary widely – we ask experts how to find good deals
articles.summary: UK shoppers hunting real Christmas trees can find Nordmann firs—the soft-needled favourite for needle retention—from £14 at discounters up to £60 for 7.5ft at B&Q; Fraser firs (citrus-cedar scent) start at £250 for 10ft. Regional growers’ prices vary, with 4ft Nordmann at £39 and Norway spruce at £26. Supermarkets like Tesco and Aldi offer pot-grown and cut trees from £15. Garden centres list cut Nordmanns at £30–£45 and pot-grown at £15 extra. Experts recommend the “bend test” for fresh needles, measuring space before buying, cutting the base for water uptake and maintaining hydration using quality stands.

articles.title: What links Amy Adams, Teri Hatcher and Margot Kidder? The Saturday quiz
articles.trailText: From Cecil at Waitrose and Slinky at Tesco to an app designed to be deleted, test your knowledge with the Saturday quiz
articles.summary: The Saturday quiz features 15 trivia and linking questions: from Australia’s 1932 war on emus and the Sagrada Família as the world’s tallest church, to the ‘See it, say it, sorted’ rail announcement, Obama’s mother named Stanley, Germany’s Tatort drama, Everton’s lost heritage stadium, the delete-designed Hinge app and Nirvana’s Nevermind cover. Linking rounds connect actresses who played Lois Lane, global Monopoly Mayfair equivalents, the River Jordan, the primate “trimates,” £50 note figures, M&S cake mascots and recurring wives’ names.

articles.title: What does your earlobe do and are there wild camels? The kids’ quiz
articles.trailText: Five multiple-choice questions – set by children – to test your knowledge, and a chance to submit your own junior brainteasers for future quizzes
articles.summary: Molly Oldfield’s kids’ quiz features five child-set multiple-choice questions exploring anatomy (earlobe function), wildlife (wild camels), and more. Readers can test their knowledge and submit their own junior brainteasers for future quizzes. The quiz ties into Oldfield’s Everything Under the Sun series, including the original podcast and three books: Everything Under the Sun, the Quiz Book, and All Around the World.

articles.title: Tim Dowling: our dog is bottom of the class at dog school
articles.trailText: The school has provided us with a whistle, which we can add to the long list of noises that the dog is afraid of
articles.summary: Tim Dowling’s family dog is dead last at dog school despite excelling only at sustained eye contact. At home she obeys basic commands but fears the high-pitched whistle meant to improve recall. On a winter beach test she inconsistently fetches her own ball, abandons it for other dogs’ games, and eagerly follows strangers’ commands instead of her owners’. With graduation looming, the couple worry they’ll be held back yet again.

articles.title: Blind date: ‘The waiters wanted an on-the-spot review of what we thought of each other’
articles.trailText: Amanda, 56, a performance assessor, meets Paul, 53, a networks manager
articles.summary: Amanda, 56, a performance assessor, and Paul, 53, a networks manager, met for a blind date at Caravelli in Loughborough. Paul, hoping for adventure and engaging company, found Amanda tall, smiley and open-minded; they covered food, wine, music, film, travel, politics and Alan Partridge, then shared drinks at a pub and exchanged a cheek peck (he scored it 10/10). Amanda, seeking spark and nervous energy, praised Paul’s fitness and adventurous spirit, navigated the bread basket, endured on-the-spot waiter feedback and gave an 8.5/10. Both want a second date.

articles.title: Why is Timothée Chalamet suddenly everywhere? Seven things you need to know – from Oscars to puppies
articles.trailText: The 29-year-old star is getting his best reviews ever for the upcoming film Marty Supreme – but he’s also making waves with his idiosyncratic approach to celebrity and maintaining his status as the internet’s boyfriend
articles.summary: Twice Oscar-nominated, Chalamet is now favourite to win Best Actor at the 2026 Oscars for Marty Supreme, a ping-pong drama praised for his charisma and backed by tongue-in-cheek marketing stunts. He is re-igniting 'Chalamania' via a viral promo skit and a sold-out Nahmias zip-up jacket hailed as 2025's defining garment. Despite his nepo-baby background, he vows to stick to film, even as whispers link him to mysterious rapper EsDeeKid. Leaked kissing photos with Gwyneth Paltrow, romance rumors about Kylie Jenner, puppy selfies and hints at future fatherhood cement his status as the internet's boyfriend.

articles.title: How to buy the greatest gifts: personal shoppers on their 17 rules for perfect presents
articles.trailText: December can bring huge stress, as people struggle with budgetary pressures, organisation and what to give the person who has everything. Here’s a guide to getting it right, every time
articles.summary: Personal shoppers advise starting early with a budgeted spreadsheet, sourcing ideas from past guides and local makers, prioritizing quality over brand and checking return policies. Opt for edible hampers or experience gifts, personalize items, upgrade everyday essentials, or choose practical but thoughtful objects. For tricky recipients (kids, Secret Santa, hard-to-buy-for), set clear budgets, be inventive with themes or charity-shop challenges, and include tasteful wrapping. Note gift receipts only for size-specific items and consider regifting unwanted items responsibly.

articles.title: The raw truth about Christmas recipes | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Naked veg | Not-so-magic mushrooms | A present from Farage | Advent calendars | Snail trail
articles.summary: A collection of five brief letters critiques the Guardian’s Christmas recipe roundup and related holiday oddities: one reader dismisses a raw-vegetables-with-olive-oil recipe as blatant non-idea; another flags Tesco’s mushroom Wellington, recalling a notorious poisoning case; a third cheers Nigel Farage’s vow to boycott the BBC as their ideal Christmas gift; a parent confesses filling an advent calendar with sprouts as a prank; and one correspondent exposes snail farms hiding behind shell companies for tax avoidance. The feature closes by inviting readers to submit letters for publication.

articles.title: Are you leaning into Christmas this year? We’d like to hear from you
articles.trailText: Perhaps you started Christmas earlier or are making extra special efforts to enjoy the festive season
articles.summary: The Guardian’s Life & Style section is inviting readers to share how they’re ‘leaning in’ to Christmas this year—such as putting up trees sooner, sporting festive jumpers with extra zeal, listening to carols ahead of schedule or planning more pre-25 December gatherings. The call asks how and why readers’ seasonal routines differ from previous years, whether they’ve started festivities early, what’s prompted the change and if it’s enhancing their enjoyment. Responses are collected via an online form (with links to terms and privacy).

articles.title: Colin Friels: ‘We’re only here for a very brief time, so you may as well enjoy the living daylights out of it’
articles.trailText: The beloved actor on elusive retirement, sharing the stage with his daughter, and the secret to a long and strong marriage
articles.summary: At 73, veteran actor Colin Friels vows Belvoir’s production of King Lear will likely be his last stage role, despite having sworn off theatre in 2013. He shares the title part with his daughter Charlotte as Goneril, reflecting on rigorous rehearsals, a past on-stage collapse in 2012, and his calming bond with stock horses. Married over 40 years to Judy Davis, Friels credits friendship and respect for their strong union. He emphasizes life’s brevity, gratitude, reverence for the everyday, and no plans to truly retire.

articles.title: Composting for your garden? This ancient method requires minimal effort
articles.trailText: Digging a trench alongside your vegetable bed is an easy way to dispose of food and plant waste, and enrich soil for next year’s crops
articles.summary: Trench composting involves digging a 20–60 cm trench alongside or within next year’s vegetable beds, filling it with fruit and vegetable scraps, garden waste, grass clippings and leaves, and covering it to decompose over months. This low-effort, space-saving alternative to traditional heaps or bins requires no turning or exact green/brown ratios and can be tarpaulin-covered to deter wildlife. Ideal when renovating perennial beds or constructing raised beds—simply layer organic matter before filling—trench composting enriches soil structure naturally and prepares a fertile bed for the following growing season.

articles.title: Experience: I gave birth to the world’s first IVF boy
articles.trailText: My husband and I were unable to have children, and then we heard about a new experimental technique
articles.summary: In 1972 in Bishopbriggs near Glasgow, aged 26, the author discovered her blocked fallopian tubes made natural conception impossible. After failed surgery and adoption barriers, she applied to Patrick Steptoe and Robert Edwards’ free experimental IVF program. Her first attempt in February 1977 failed, but her second succeeded: on 14 January 1979, during a snowstorm, she gave birth via caesarean to son Alastair, the world’s first IVF boy, weighing 5lb 12oz. Now 46 and a Royal Fleet Auxiliary first officer, Alastair remains her pride. She cherishes bonds with four fellow participants and honors the pioneers who enabled over 13 million IVF births.

articles.title: ‘Look what you’ve done to my children!’: a tale of winter wonderland disasters
articles.trailText: These events are meant to make Christmas magical, and while many do, a few fall spectacularly short. Here, in no particular order, are some of the worst offenders
articles.summary: Brits shell out big for “magical” Christmas events that underdeliver—from the 2025 Rudolph drone show in Haywards Heath (a 600-drone display that failed, lasted 15 minutes, canceled its finale) to a litany of decade-long disasters: 2008’s Lapland New Forest (broken rink, plastic bears, jailed organisers); 2013 Milton Keynes winter fair (burger vans, no rides); 2014 Sutton’s Magical Journey (one-day flop); 2019 Harrods grotto (£2k spenders only); 2022 Enchanted Balgone’s empty Santa shed; and 2024 Bluewater Elf on the Shelf’s bare retail unit before its Bluey reboot.

articles.title: Sharing the bill  and sharing a bed | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Dating dinosaurs | Quaker community | Unusual place names | Films on boats
articles.summary: Readers of the Guardian’s letters page challenge Scott Galloway’s claim that women don’t date men who split the bill, arguing that insisting on paying undermines female independence and that wealth can even be a turn-off. Another shares how Quaker “Advices and Queries” (especially “Live adventurously”) provided unexpected comfort in grief. Others playfully debate odd English place names—No Place, Pity Me, Quaking Houses, Titty Ho—and nominate The Maggie as the quintessential boat-based film. The section closes by inviting more reader letters.

articles.title: My son is a voracious reader, but he judges books by their covers. How can I help him see past them? | Leading questions
articles.trailText: When you make art proof of virtue, you can make it feel like a drag, advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith writes. Instead, encourage him to develop his own sensibility
articles.summary: An 8½-year-old avid reader dismisses books by unappealing cover art, skipping blurbs or sample pages. His mother wants him to judge on content rather than illustration. Advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith recommends channeling his visual interest: wrap gifts in plain paper or let him design and swap in personalized covers, explore what makes an image ‘fit’ a story, and discuss his preferences. This creative collaboration nurtures his own aesthetic sensibility, deepens engagement with texts and preserves reading as joyful exploration.

articles.title: What to drink on Christmas Day, from morning to night
articles.trailText: From morning drinks to nolo suggestions for the non-drinkers, and from stocking fillers to showstoppers and after-dinner port
articles.summary: Hannah Crosbie, a wine writer, urges planning Christmas drinks in advance, pairing beverages to each moment. Morning: Castellore Organico Prosecco Rosé, Ca’ di Rajo Lemoss Frizzante, Westwell Wicken Foy English sparkling or Telmont Champagne. Non-drinkers: Copenhagen Sparkling Tea, Oddbird Spumante, Bunta citrus lager or Pentire Coastal Spritz. Stocking fillers: Pure Fire cocktail, Moth Paloma, La Vieille Ferme rosé can, M&S limoncello spritz. Main event: On Point Australian Chenin Blanc, Les Terrasses St Nicolas de Bourgueil Cabernet Franc, Lyrarakis Assyrtiko-Vidiano orange wine, Ridge Three Valleys Zinfandel. After dinner: The Society’s Sauternes, Kopke tawny port, Black Lines Oatnog or H by Hine VSOP cognac.

articles.title: You be the judge: Should my best friend stop trying to set me up on dates?
articles.trailText: Whitney thinks Haile would be happier in a relationship. Haile says she’s fine by herself. You decide who’s being too single-minded
articles.summary: Haile, 28, has embraced independence since her breakup a year ago and loves her solo life, but best friend Whitney, a serial dater, keeps urging her to get back into the dating scene—arranging setups, hosting couples’ dinner parties and insisting on kids rhetoric. Haile resents feeling pitied or pressured, arguing singleness is a choice, not a waiting room. Whitney insists she just wants Haile to be happy and socially connected. Guardian readers largely side with respecting Haile’s autonomy over matchmaking.

articles.title: Thursday news quiz: final curtain calls and fiendish questions
articles.trailText: 25 questions on notable pop culture, sporting and political figures we lost this year. How will you fare?
articles.summary: The Guardian’s Thursday quiz No 226 — the annual In Memoriam edition — features 25 fiendish general-knowledge questions on pop-culture, sporting and political figures we lost this year. There’s no prize beyond the chance to exercise your memory and honor these personalities through obscure trivia. Readers are invited to share their scores in the comments and can lodge fact-checking complaints with evidence if they spot an error. A reflective, festive twist on the weekly news quiz.

articles.title: The single-parent penalty: why do they get such a poor deal on family tickets?
articles.trailText: Major attractions often don’t take lone-parent families into account in their pricing structures, making days out more expensive
articles.summary: Many UK attractions still base family fares on two adults, penalizing 2 million single-parent households—often low earners—with no or smaller discounts. Gingerbread’s National Trust pilot granting free tickets underscored the social value of affordable days out. A survey by ALVA finds 41% of families mismatched by existing offers. Spot checks at venues from Hampton Court and Cineworld to historic sites show lone parents with one or two children pay as much as or more than two-adult groups. Some museums (eg Bletchley Park, National Trust) now offer better lone-parent deals. ALVA urges more inclusive pricing to balance accessibility and costs.

articles.title: A moment that changed me: My unbearable grief kept growing – until I found solace in a silent community
articles.trailText: After my dad died, I tried to cope by keeping busy: a day job, a side hustle, socialising and working out. But I kept bursting into tears in public. At a Quaker meeting, it was as if someone had turned down the volume of the world
articles.summary: After his father died of a rare blood disease in 2022, a 28-year-old Londoner quit his PhD, moved home and overloaded himself with work, socialising, side hustles and gym sessions to suppress his grief, only to burst into tears in public. During a lunch-break stroll he discovered Friends House, the central Quaker meeting in London, and was drawn to its values—truth, simplicity, equality, peace. Attending silent worship helped him face his emotions. Regular Quaker meetings, community and pacifist faith transformed his tidal wave of grief into gentle ripples, teaching patience, self-care and a “quiet faith” rooted in stillness.

articles.title: Understanding the role of fascia in keeping the body healthy | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to an article by Joel Snape that explores the importance of fascia
articles.summary: Letters responding to Joel Snape’s article underline fascia’s emerging role in health, spotlighting Prof Robert Schleip’s Fascia Research Group at Ulm, Harvard’s 2015 fascia–acupuncture–oncology conference and historic osteopathic founder Andrew Taylor Still. Writers praise gentle manual therapies (Bowen, Feldenkrais, Rolfing), yin yoga’s gravity-assisted meridian stretches and parasympathetic benefits, and myofascial release for fibromyalgia pain relief, complemented by reformer Pilates and memory-foam bedding. Traditional Chinese medicine locates meridians within the continuous fascial network, explaining acupuncture’s deep relaxation effects. Collectively, these insights underscore fascia’s sensitivity and feedback loop to central and autonomic nervous systems and its foundational role in holistic medicine.

articles.title: The art of tablescaping | Jess Cartner-Morley
articles.trailText: Laying a table well is one of the best ways to make guests feel relaxed and cosy. Queen of tablescaping Laura Jackson’s advice? Forget the stiff old rules and have fun with it
articles.summary: Journalist Jess Cartner-Morley profiles tablescaping expert Laura Jackson, who urges hosts to ditch formal rules—mix patterns and glassware, focus on warmth and playfulness. Key tips: limit cutlery and glasses to essentials, scatter candles and soft linens, use low decorations for easy conversation, repurpose ribbons, foliage and fruit peelers for personal touches. Christmas feasts benefit from cosy lighting, red accents and communal seating, but quick, flexible styling beats perfection. Tablescaping is about creating a relaxed, inviting atmosphere that amplifies togetherness and festive cheer rather than showcasing etiquette.

articles.title: ‘A doll to me and a trumptet to Jimmie’: six-year-old girl’s letter to Santa in 1883
articles.trailText: Janet’s wishlist, which ran in Leeds Mercury, and letter from Hampshire girl in 1898 unearthed in newspaper archives
articles.summary: Researchers at Ancestry have unearthed one of Britain’s earliest known letters to Santa, penned in 1883 by six-year-old Janet and published verbatim in the Leeds Mercury. In her idiosyncratic spelling, she asks for “a Doll … with a cRAdel” for herself, “a TRuMPtet to JiMMie” and treats parents too. The article traces how letter-writing to Santa grew in the US after the Civil War, merged with England’s Father Christmas by the 1880s, and highlights a similarly virtuous 1898 plea from 11-year-old Mabel Hancock, underscoring the enduring childlike tradition.

articles.title: Toto carrying the rings at Albanese’s wedding is nothing new as more pets join couples saying ‘I do’ | Kate Leaver
articles.trailText: The Australian prime minister and Jodie Haydon’s cavoodle had a critical role to play as ring-bearer, while more brides and grooms bring a pet to their big day
articles.summary: Australian PM Anthony Albanese and partner Jodie Haydon enlisted their cavoodle Toto—escorted down the aisle by their niece—as ring-bearer at their wedding, spotlighting a growing trend: half of Australian couples now plan to include dogs in ceremonies, with a quarter naming them ring-bearer or bridesmaid. While New York pets can officially witness marriages with paw-printed licenses, Australian dogs perform predictable duties—walking down the aisle, carrying rings, posing for photos—and some couples hire professional chaperones like Perth’s Wedding Tails (from $500) for supervision, first aid, and stress management. Experts advise ensuring pets are well adjusted, comfortable in crowds and climate, citing dogs as ideal wedding additions if properly prepared.

articles.title: Houseplant hacks: how can I stop my plants dying when I turn on the central heating?
articles.trailText: Ease your houseplants into winter by giving them a seasonal reset and moving them away from radiators
articles.summary: Houseplants suffer rapid moisture loss when you switch on central heating: warm, dry air strips water from leaves and soil, creating arid microclimates. Mistaken for life-giving sunlight, radiator heat dehydrates plants like a slow cooker. Prevent this by performing a pre-heating reset: relocate pots at least 0.5m from radiators or vents, group them to boost local humidity or set out water bowls, top-dress soil with fresh compost, trim yellowing leaves and dust foliage, then water sparingly. Finally, let plants settle in bright, indirect light. This aligns with slowing winter growth, minimises temperature shock and keeps foliage supple.

articles.title: Saunas, skating and celebratory toilet seats: 25 ways to get into the Christmas spirit
articles.trailText: Are you feeling festive? If not, here are some great and unexpected shortcuts, from fish pie to ‘intermittent wrapping’ to watching a seasonal film every day of December
articles.summary: 25 contributors share unconventional ways to spark Christmas cheer: from ice skating at Somerset House, Hampton Court and Leicester Square, to hunting quirky mermaid baubles and lugging a 7ft tree home. Traditions include fish pie on Christmas Eve; ‘intermittent wrapping’ and festive dinnerware rituals; carol descants and seasonal coffee tastings; baking biscuits for neighbors; rereading Santaland Diaries; pudding basin hunts; homemade photo Christmas cards; outdoor sauna and cold plunge sessions under twinkling lights; cake decorating; daily December film viewings; clementine cake baking; felt stocking decorations; wreath-making; vintage festive TV specials; vinyl jazz soundtracks; elf-approved wrapping paper collection; and even Santa-themed toilet seats.

articles.title: Ravneet Gill and Mattie Taiano’s recipes for a Friendmas sharing menu
articles.trailText: The husband and wife team cook up a storm with lamb shoulder, dauphinoise and brown sugar meringues – just don’t ask them who’s doing the cleaning up
articles.summary: Pastry chef Ravneet Gill and husband Mattie Taiano, co-owners of Gina in Chingford, share their informal ‘Friendmas’ dinner approach: communal, drop-off style gatherings focused on seasonal sharing dishes such as slow-braised lamb shoulder with dauphinoise, simple pastas, and brown sugar meringues with coffee cream and cherries. Drawing on their Indian, Italian and Jewish roots and memories of open-door family feasts, they favour make-ahead recipes and stress practical tips—shoes off, bring bottles, arrive on time—while lamenting post-party clean-ups in their one-bed flat.

articles.title: Gratitude can be truly healing – but you need more than a checklist
articles.trailText: Transformative gratitude occurs within sincere relationships, but building those links is not always an easy process
articles.summary: Psychotherapist Moya Sarner argues that authentic gratitude isn’t built from checklists but emerges spontaneously within honest, vulnerable relationships. She cautions that gaming gratitude—like keeping a diary—yields only fleeting “nice feelings,” not the deep change real gratitude sparks. Drawing on her own psychoanalysis—where conflict and sincere dialogue with her analyst sparked profound clarity—she shows gratitude as both trigger and outcome of psychological growth. It requires tolerating envy, rage and despair, then forging mental links with others. Over twenty months of her fortnightly column she’s nurtured these links with readers grieving loss or seeking therapy. Like psychodynamic change, genuine gratitude ripples outward, deepening over time to sustain emotional wellbeing.

articles.title: Is it true that … a glass of wine a day is good for your heart?
articles.trailText: Moderate wine consumption may benefit your cardiac health, but foods such as grapes and berries offer similar advantages without the negative effects
articles.summary: Consultant cardiologist Dr Oliver Guttmann warns that although moderate wine intake can lower LDL cholesterol through vasorelaxant and anti-inflammatory compounds and antioxidants like resveratrol, alcohol carries risks including hypertension, liver disease, digestive, mental health and immune issues, and is classified by the WHO as a group 1 carcinogen. Similar heart-protective effects are available from grapes and berries without alcohol’s downsides. Experts advise strict moderation: no more than 14 units weekly (six medium glasses) or 20 small glasses a month, alongside a healthy diet.

articles.title: ‘Albo said how much he loved them’: bespoke beers just the thing for an Australian prime minister’s wedding
articles.trailText: Creating customised cans for Anthony Albanese and Jodie Haydon’s big day was a first for Sydney’s Willie the Boatman brewery. But personalised nuptial drinks are a growing trend
articles.summary: Willie the Boatman brewery in Sydney made the first bespoke beer cans for prime minister Anthony Albanese and Jodie Haydon’s wedding, reflecting a booming trend in personalised nuptial drinks. Founder Pat McInerney created a custom pale ale featuring the couple’s portraits and supplied 16 cases, which Albanese praised. Wedding planners report rising demand for branded cocktails, custom-labelled wines or beers, and even entirely new brews. Vendors from mobile cocktail vans to distilleries like Archie Rose and wineries like Dormilona now tailor drinks from labels to recipes. (Article amended to correct Darcy Allen’s name.)

articles.title: What are the greatest life lessons?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: The Guardian’s long-running 'Readers Answer Readers' series asks: What are the biggest life lessons—from navigating uncertainty and building resilience to everyday secrets like laundry combinations—that took years to learn and deserve sharing? In this thread, questions span trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts, inviting both micro-lessons like optimal clothing care and macro-advice on embracing ambiguity. Participants can post responses and fresh questions in comments or email tips at nq@theguardian.com, covering life hacks (e.g., never washing reds with whites) and broader strategies for coping with change and pursuing fulfillment. Selected submissions will be curated and published next Sunday.

articles.title: The kindness of strangers: a concierge gave me his mother’s opera ticket
articles.trailText: I was travelling with my parents and discovered that Don Giovanni was being performed while we were there. I simply had to try to see it
articles.summary: At 20 the author became an opera devotee after seeing the Don Giovanni film. While traveling in 1980s France with her parents, she discovered a sold-out staging of Don Giovanni in Avignon starring José van Dam. The hotel concierge surprised her by gifting her his mother’s premium ticket at no cost. That night’s flawless view and elegant atmosphere left an indelible mark. Now 66, she remembers that stranger’s generosity as she continues to enjoy opera on vinyl.

articles.title: What to do with a sparse tree? Or a wonky angel? Shop window-dressers on 11 ways to make your home look amazing at Christmas
articles.trailText: There’s a lot of pressure to make a splash, but you can create beautiful festive decor on a budget – just ask the people who do it all year round
articles.summary: Visual merchandisers share 11 budget-friendly Christmas decor tips: plan year-round around a clear theme and color palette; choose between a maximalist or understated style; pick a well-shaped or fully fluffed tree and fill sparse spots with foliage; layer ornaments deeply, use fine-wire lights and candles for depth; embrace DIY wreaths, paper chains and crackers; repurpose ribbons and broken baubles; bring greenery indoors; and transform your table with mixed vessels, moss, blooms and taper candles for a warm, layered look.

articles.title: If toxic humility is a thing, I definitely have it. But perhaps there’s another way | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: We’re taught that modesty is good and pride is bad. This ignores the fact that telling ourselves we’re OK is actually beneficial, writes Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Emma Beddington reflects on ‘toxic humility’—the ingrained tendency to self-deprecate despite inner self-worth. Prompted by Stylist’s Love Yourself campaign, she details how cultural norms like Scandinavia’s Jante law and Britain’s distrust of pride reinforce modesty. Contrasted with performative boasts from LinkedIn braggarts and Trump-style grandiosity, Beddington argues self-affirmation—backed by a meta-study of 129 papers—improves wellbeing for two weeks. She urges small daily self-compliments to build self-love muscles.

articles.title: Readers reply: Which old Christmas traditions should be revived?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: Guardian readers suggest a range of pre-Victorian and folk customs to counter modern consumerism: door-to-door wassailing to toast neighbours’ health; calling the season ‘Yule’; Victorian parlour games like snapdragons; a green-robed Father Christmas; keeping greenery and lights until Candlemas; illustrated Advent calendars and making a Blue Peter Advent crown; celebrating Saturnalia’s gift-giving roots; a low-key Scandinavian julbord instead of a roast; Boxing Day shopping bans; Krampus parades; the Rauhnächte laundry ban; richer Twelfth Night feasts; and reviving mistletoe, indoor trees and warm fairy lights.

articles.title: Cariad Lloyd and Rachel Parris look back: ‘We’ve been through a lot – trying for children, losing parents … but our friendship is constant’
articles.trailText: The comedians on their first meeting, pissing each other off, and a shared obsession with Pride and Prejudice
