articles.summary: Cariad Lloyd (b. 1982) and Rachel Parris (b. 1984) met through improv in 2011 and co-created Austentatious—an improvised Jane Austen show now running at London’s Vaudeville—bonding over Pride & Prejudice as their ’Bonnets’ duo. Cariad’s mischievous, edgy comedy complements Rachel’s classier wit; together they’ve built a 14-year creative partnership that spans stage, the podcast Griefcast, Weirdos Book Club, The Mash Report and Rachel’s upcoming Pride & Prejudice novel. Offstage, they’ve supported each other through parental bereavements, fertility struggles and baby loss, forging an uncommon blend of emotional alchemy and steadfast friendship.

articles.title: Dining across the divide: ‘I was nervous – was he going to attack me for being a snowflake?’
articles.trailText: A Green-party globalist and a right-of-centre Tory clash over immigration. Would they see eye to eye over reparations?
articles.summary: Peter, 34, a Green-Party globalist and ex-civil servant studying public health, and Akshat, 43, a Conservative-voting risk manager from India, meet for a two-and-a-half-hour dinner at Huo Belsize Village. They debate immigration—Akshat likens migrants to salt in a dish, Peter critiques the UK’s hostile environment—and agree controlled migration and wealth creation benefit society. Both call out politics and media for stoking division. On reparations, Peter urges a moral reckoning beyond payouts; Akshat argues history can’t be judged by today’s standards. They part more open to dialogue.

articles.title: This is how we do it: ‘I have an urgent desire to have group sex – and I want Sophie to join me on this journey’
articles.trailText: For John, group sex is a fantasy he’s long wanted to experience. For Sophie, it is a mistake she does not want to repeat
articles.summary: John, 51, widowed, wakes to an urgent desire to experience group sex with his new partner Sophie after reconnecting with his sexuality. He longs to realize a lifelong fantasy, driven by regret and existential urgency post-loss. Initially Sophie, 50, was open, recounting past lockdown group encounters, but now, balancing single motherhood and self-worth beyond people-pleasing, she refuses. Their bond is strong yet threatened: John battles jealousy, insecurity and grief; Sophie upholds boundaries to protect their loving monogamy, fearing regret and the loss of their intimacy.

articles.title: I want be a single mum, but feel envious of peers with partners | Ask Annalisa Barbieri
articles.trailText: It is good that you are getting expert counselling, but seeking support from other solo mums might be helpful too
articles.summary: 36-year-old woman, after a decade of dating, chooses single motherhood but experiences grief, envy of partnered friends and doubts about being ‘unlovable’. Psychotherapist Julia Bueno and advisor Annalisa Barbieri validate these painful feelings as common for solo mums-to-be, rooted in thwarted reproductive narratives and childhood insecurities. They recommend acknowledging loss alongside positivity, writing a compassionate letter to her grieving self, joining peer support (via clinic, Gingerbread, Donor Conception Network) and reading Susan Golombok’s We Are Family to bolster resilience.

articles.title: The moment I knew: it was tender but complicated – then we decided not to hide any more
articles.trailText: When mountaineer Allie Pepper met Mikel Sherpa at Manaslu base camp in Nepal, their romance began with stolen kisses and whispered conversations
articles.summary: Allie Pepper, a veteran mountaineer pursuing the world’s 14 highest peaks without supplemental oxygen, met Sherpa guide Mikel at Manaslu base camp in September 2022. Their playful, rain-soaked encounters—umbrella stealing, late-night kisses and whispered conversations—grew into a secret romance fraught with a 15-year age gap and her recent divorce. Reunited in Pakistan at K2’s base, they decided to go public, forging a partnership that’s since conquered seven 8,000-metre summits. Devoted to each other and to the mountains, they balance personal dreams with shared adventures. "I love me, you love you…"

articles.title: ‘Desire in one of its rawest forms’: what do we know about limerence?
articles.trailText: For everything from pop music to poetry, overwhelming infatuation offers inspiration and storylines. But when might this tip over into something a little less healthy?
articles.summary: Limerence, a term coined in the 1970s by psychologist Dorothy Tennov, describes overwhelming, involuntary romantic obsession marked by intrusive thoughts, emotional volatility and compulsive behaviors like constant phone-checking and fantasy replay. Though not a DSM-5 diagnosis, experts distinguish it from passionate love and from clinical erotomania: it’s driven by anxiety over uncertain or intermittent contact, amplified today by social media and loneliness. In moderate forms it can spur creativity, but when it disrupts work, self-esteem or crosses boundaries, therapy is advised to regulate emotions, challenge idealisation and address attachment wounds. Philosophers also see in limerence a raw glimpse of human desire and vulnerability.

articles.title: ‘When I saw what I captured I felt a Muybridge-like joy’: Roger Tooth’s best phone picture
articles.trailText: Tooth was delighted to capture one of Antony Gormley’s statues on Crosby beach – the dog was an unexpected bonus
articles.summary: Retired Guardian photography chief Roger Tooth used his iPhone in October 2025 to capture Antony Gormley’s 100 cast-iron lifesize Another Place sculptures erected two decades earlier on Crosby beach amid Storm Amy’s swirling sands. On a weekend trip after visiting the Walker, he snapped a close-up when a small white dog — later dubbed “Snowy” — hurdled into frame. Tooth was thrilled to see all four legs suspended mid-air, evoking Eadweard Muybridge’s studies, and felt a “Muybridge-like joy” at proving canine flight with a phone camera.

articles.title: How big is an elephant’s brain and why are cacti spiky? The kids’ quiz
articles.trailText: Five multiple-choice questions – set by children – to test your knowledge, and a chance to submit your own junior brainteasers for future quizzes
articles.summary: This five-question multiple-choice quiz, created by children and hosted by Molly Oldfield on her Everything Under the Sun podcast, challenges you to explain why cacti have spines, how an elephant’s brain measures up, and more curious facts about nature. Perfect for young science buffs, it also invites kids to submit their own brainteasers for future quizzes. Oldfield’s related titles include Everything Under the Sun, its Quiz Book spin-off, and her new All Around the World edition.

articles.title: What links Marc Almond and chemist John Farrow? The Saturday quiz
articles.trailText: From Charon, Styx and Nix to Dr Fink and Bobby Z, test your knowledge with the Saturday quiz
articles.summary: This Saturday quiz presents 15 trivia questions spanning art (Vermeer’s Girl with a Pearl Earring), astronomy (Pluto’s satellites), historical passports, Maltese architecture, TikTok influencers, Victorian bestsellers, British racecourses and music (Prince’s Revolution), then asks link questions on Peak District rivers, former plastic-pitch football clubs, Good Friday events, Oscar character names, aeronautical forces, surname puns (partners named Ball) and eagle-derived place names. Answers reveal patterns across geography, history, science, sport and pop culture.

articles.title: Blind date: ‘I hadn’t been on a date for nearly 15 years and it showed’
articles.trailText: Sarah, 53, a psychologist, meets Russell, 61, a behaviour officer
articles.summary: Psychologist Sarah (53) and behaviour officer Russell (61) meet at Nottingham’s Bar Iberico on a Guardian blind date, each seeking connection: Sarah hoping for romance or new company, Russell for an intelligent “chinwag.” Over tapas they discuss Montessori, Iceland whale-watching, tree-planting and Italian family traditions. Both rate manners highly. Russell confesses a 15-year dating hiatus left him overtalkative. Sarah labels Russell loquacious, big-hearted, unconventional (7/10); Russell calls Sarah interesting, adventurous, attractive (9/10). No kiss or second romance, but they swap numbers to visit Bempton Cliffs puffins as friends.

articles.title: Tim Dowling: how did I end up on a helpline for the old and befuddled?
articles.trailText: The online banker sounds concerned, as if he’s trying to keep me on the line until the ambulance arrives
articles.summary: While home alone, Dowling gets a text alert that his bank updated his address—an action he didn’t request. Calling the helpline, he endures unhelpful voice menus, re-enters IDs, and chooses hold music before finally reaching 'Gareth' from the 60+ customers team. Spoken to in a patronising, slow tone, he theorises an account migration triggered the warning. After verifying balances he knows nothing of, he hangs up feeling enfeebled and puzzled why a benign update labelled him 'old and befuddled.'

articles.title: Celebrity crib sheet: Katy Perry has spent all year in the headlines – here are the six things you need to know
articles.trailText: She made a short, and much-ridiculed, trip to space. She tried to buy a house and fell foul of public opinion. And she’s found love, apparently, with Justin Trudeau. Time to get up to speed before this singer next hits the headlines
articles.summary: In 2025, Katy Perry made headlines for six episodes: she won a $1.8m judgment against Carl Westcott over a $15m Montecito mansion sale but faced blowback for suing an 85-year-old veteran; her hammy Blue Origin spaceflight—singing “What a Wonderful World” in orbit—drew ridicule and flat-earth conspiracies; devoted fans funded a Times Square billboard in her honor; her Lifetimes tour received mixed reviews; she finalized her split from fiancé Orlando Bloom; and she’s now romantically linked with former Canadian PM Justin Trudeau, sparking yacht rendezvous photos and Paris outings.

articles.title: Fine dining in your front room: from tea bags to ceramics, top restaurant essentials to transform meals at home
articles.trailText: Never mind the food, what about the vibe? Restaurateurs share tips and tricks that will bring a touch of restaurant magic to your table
articles.summary: UK restaurateurs reveal how to recreate restaurant magic at home through curated details: invest in refined glassware (Ikea Storsint £12/6–Richard Brendon £96/2), artisan hand soaps (£18/500ml), high-grade olive oils (Two Fields £18.50/500ml–Trulli Ulivi £22.50), bespoke cutlery (£711–£995), ambient lighting (Pooky £130, Zafferano £118), layered table linens, curated coffee/tea blends, bespoke vinyl playlists, seasonal flowers and handmade ceramics or tiled accents. These touches—from scent to sound—transform everyday meals into fine-dining experiences.

articles.title: Let the city’s pretty mews be your muse for container planting
articles.trailText: I study these cobbled backstreets for inspiration. But whatever plants you choose, adhere to basic rules that make for a successful container garden
articles.summary: After 15 years in London—seven growing on balconies and, since 2020, with a garden—Helen skips the glare of West End window boxes to explore quiet cobbled mews bursting with rag-tag pots. She emptied her old containers and refills them by following core design rules: choose ample pots, ensure cohesion, vary heights and seasons, avoid a horticultural jumble. Plant a small tree (eg Amelanchier lamarckii) for structure, an evergreen like Fatsia japonica for winter interest, and trailing vines (Muehlenbeckia complexa, ivies) to unify layers. The result: resilient, self-sufficient, year-round displays.

articles.title: Small talk: a bluffer’s guide
articles.trailText: Dread the thought of party chat? This selection of cultural keypoints will put some fizz in your conversation
articles.summary: A handy guide to party pleasantries, from speculating which shows Trump might cancel next and debating Spotify boycotts over AI-warfare investments, to naming comedians who’ve played Saudi festivals. Quiz guests on LA’s upcoming AI art museum and Kathryn Bigelow’s nuke thriller A House of Dynamite. Brush up on Swift’s latest album feud with Charli XCX, Erling Haaland’s classical music playlist, and celebrity line-ups for the next series of Celebrity Traitors to banish awkward silences at any dinner.

articles.title: How do I respond to someone who says ‘I’m not racist, but ... ’? | Leading questions
articles.trailText: It’s important to express your disagreement: for their sake as much as yours, writes advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith . But first decide on what you aim to accomplish
articles.summary: Eleanor Gordon-Smith advises that when someone prefaced by “I’m not racist, but…” makes a prejudiced remark, it’s important to express disagreement—for their benefit as much as yours. First decide whether you want to register dissent or aim to persuade, as each goal requires different tactics. To record dissent, prepare brief “block” phrases (“I don’t share that view…”). To persuade, listen, empathise and build trust. Alternatively, deploy gentle Socratic questions to expose contradictions. Lasting change often hinges on shifting power, not just attitudes.

articles.title: Europol seizes 8m fake and harmful toys in pre-Christmas crackdown
articles.trailText: Agency warns shoppers to be vigilant online and on the high street, with counterfeit items often posing health risks
articles.summary: Europol has seized over 8 million counterfeit and harmful toys in coordinated raids across 26 EU countries as part of Operation Ludus, raising the two-year total to nearly 17 million. Most items, originating from China and trafficked via Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey, include fake dolls, building bricks, toy cars, cuddly toys and games lacking EU safety labels. Hazards cited range from choking on small parts and magnets to chemical exposure, fire and strangulation risks. Authorities warn shoppers to buy only trusted, compliant products and flagged illegal listings on platforms such as Shein and Temu, urging vigilance when Christmas shopping online.

articles.title: One-hour party plan | Felicity Cloake
articles.trailText: Don’t panic if you’ve left it late to plan your gathering – follow these tips for whipping up an instant party atmosphere
articles.summary: Felicity Cloake’s one-hour party plan: choose a simple theme (e.g. Scandinavian or Mexican Christmas) to guide a supermarket dash, buy one alcoholic and one non-alcoholic drink, stock up abundantly on matching nibbles (crisps, nuts, olives, cheese or pie), pre-mix cocktails and punch with citrus garnish, delegate topping up, avoid fussy platters, set out glasses, ice, corkscrew, napkins and separate bins for rubbish and recycling, chill drinks first, light lamps or fairy lights, queue a long playlist—then get yourself ready and enjoy.

articles.title: London has plenty of posh breakfast options – but give me a greasy spoon any day | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: The food’s better, the price is better and the company is better. You know where you are at a proper caff, writes Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles recounts his early-morning Soho routine with two friends, opting for a no-frills greasy spoon over pricier, upscale breakfast spots. The caff delivers better-value—avoiding feeling “three off the tee” after a costly meal—superior dishes like top-notch eggs Benedict, tea in mugs, plus an authentic ambience among tradespeople doing practical labor. He contrasts this with opaque white-collar diners nibbling pricey morsels on china plates. Savouring his second mug of tea, Chiles relishes feeling more at ease with honest workers and reflecting that AI won’t soon replace their crafts.

articles.title: Tell us about the worst behaviour you’ve witnessed on a flight
articles.trailText: As Sean Duffy has urged passengers to mind their manners, we would like to hear about the worst breaches of airline etiquette that you’ve seen
articles.summary: US transportation secretary Sean Duffy has launched a civility campaign urging travellers to ditch pajamas and slippers in favour of smart attire, keep children’s behaviour in check and maintain basic manners. The Guardian now invites readers to recount the worst breaches of airline etiquette they’ve witnessed—whether drunken outbursts, seat-recline disputes, cabin fights or other untoward in-flight behaviour. Examples might include gatehold tantrums, overhead bin wars or seat-swapping spats. Submit your anecdotes via the online form (see terms and privacy details). If you encounter issues with the form, click the help link on the page.

articles.title: ‘It was no longer a gift for my husband. It was all for me’: four women on how boudoir photography changed their lives
articles.trailText: Now a hugely popular photographic genre, many women pay thousands to have intimate portraits taken of themselves by a professional. What do they get out of it?
articles.summary: Boudoir photography, once a wedding add-on, is now a standalone genre costing thousands of dollars, drawing women from brides to cancer survivors, professionals and mothers. In shoots led by JoAnna Moore and Shawn Black, clients undress to confront self-doubt, capturing raw vulnerability and strength in a scripted reveal slideshow. Sessions eschew retouching—showcasing scars, stretch marks and natural lines as authenticity. Participants, including Brittany Witt, Susan Lausier, Makeda Blake-Robinson and Kay Davies, describe a magical internal shift that endures, reshaping confidence, relationships and self-perception.

articles.title: You be the judge: should my partner stop compressing the coffee in the moka pot?
articles.trailText: Hamad thinks his method enhances the flavour. Lucia says he’s breaking all the sacred rules. Who needs to wake up and smell the coffee?
articles.summary: Lucia, raised in Italy, insists her partner Hamad abandon his practice of tamping moka pot grounds—she argues it hisses, risks damage, breaks a sacred Italian rule, and she even polled her Italian friends. He, an India-raised barista, counters that compressing grounds boosts flavour via pressure, notes his moka pot never hisses, and dismisses her peer criticism as food fascism. Their clash spotlights cultural coffee rituals versus innovation; their son Noah is caught between methods. Guardian readers weigh mixed verdicts in a poll asking: should Hamad stop compressing his partner’s moka pot?

articles.title: Thursday news quiz: blindside shocks, volcano rocks and an airport pub unlocks
articles.trailText: Test yourself on topical news trivia, pop culture and general knowledge every Thursday. How will you fare?
articles.summary: Each Thursday, The Guardian’s general knowledge quiz serves 15 topical questions blending news trivia and pop culture with playful mischief. Issue No. 225 ditches theatre references in favor of blindside shocks, volcanic eruptions, an airport pub unlocking riddle and sightings of cute dogs. Participants are invited to test themselves without prizes, silence their phones, share scores and flag any factual errors (jokes excepted) in the comments. This week’s edition also pays homage to Mancunian pop by suggesting fans revisit the Stone Roses’ Fool’s Gold.

articles.title: Two Australian homes win top places in international 2025 Dezeen awards
articles.trailText: A Dracula-inspired bathroom in Sydney and an outside-inside home in Melbourne claim interior design and architecture prizes
articles.summary: At the 2025 Dezeen Awards in London, Sydney’s Kilmory House by Jillian Dinkel won Bathroom Interior of the Year for its dramatic Dracula-inspired design, featuring stainless steel, marble, Venetian plaster and timber panelling in a 1913 stables conversion. Melbourne’s Studio Bright claimed House (Urban) of the Year for Hedge and Arbour House, a four-bedroom family home wrapped in galvanised steel mesh for climbing plants, weeks after securing the 2025 Robin Boyd Award. These wins underscore Australian excellence in heritage transformation and sustainable urban design.

articles.title: How to be a good party host (or guest) | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: From picking your guests (always add a random) and your outfit, to coping with drunks and nudity, this is what you need to know
articles.summary: Zoe Williams outlines how to host and guest with ease: hosts should stay calm—prioritizing atmosphere over perfect food or booze—while crafting guest lists (from curated pairings to wildcards), planning familiar menus and seating (alternate genders/separate couples) and sincerely accommodating dietary needs. Guests should cancel early, bring low-maintenance gifts (ice or late-day flowers), mingle beyond cliques, gauge dress codes, pace drinks by decade and navigate name-blanking via anecdotes. Handle drunks or bores by tactful intervention, and depart consistently—French exits suit some, others should announce a shared ride—ensuring every gathering feels effortless and inclusive.

articles.title: My petty gripe: bar stools – have we not suffered enough?
articles.trailText: Why must every cafe, pub, restaurant or event insist on having its patrons cosplay as babies in highchairs? Bar stools are a bonafide torture device
articles.summary: A short-height columnist vents her frustration with ubiquitous bar stools, describing them as torture devices that force dangling feet, awkward jumps and painful back hunching. Recounting a humiliating experience at Melbourne Fashion Week—perched on a waist-high stool in platforms and a short dress—she exposes how patrons risk flashing underwear or twisting ankles. Beyond personal grievance, she argues society’s seating designs neglect short people’s comfort, calling on cafés, pubs and restaurants to ditch highchairs for accessible tables and standard seats.

articles.title: $10 for a pair of used tongs? When secondhand prices are higher than new
articles.trailText: For op shops, setting prices is a delicate balance. Too high and they risk pricing out customers, too low and it becomes difficult to cover costs
articles.summary: In tip shops and op shops nationwide, secondhand prices have risen to rival or exceed retail costs, from $10 for used tongs versus $1.75 new, to overpriced toys and clothing. Market volatility and “vintage” cachet drive inflated tags that can price out low-income buyers, yet allow reuse charities to cover operating costs. Experts warn that fair pricing must balance affordability, environmental benefits, and enterprise sustainability. Ethical thrifting hinges on clear guidelines, quality assessment, and community impact.

articles.title: The death of the living room: ‘It’s hard to invite people over – not everyone wants to sit on a bed’
articles.trailText: The number of rental properties without a lounge is surging, and people are having to eat and socialise in kitchens, bedrooms and stairwells. How can you relax and build community without a communal area?
articles.summary: Rise in UK rentals without living rooms forces socialising in bedrooms/kitchens, undermining communal living and mental well-being. SpareRoom data: 29.8% of UK listings lack lounges (41.2% in London), 49% convert living rooms to bedrooms; 44% report negative mental health impact, yet 36% accept the trade-off for cheaper rent. Historical context from Edward Bok to TV-driven gatherings traces evolution of shared space. Experts warn isolation without a dedicated lounge; designers propose flexible open-plan solutions, but many tenants still struggle to build community.

articles.title: A moment that changed me: I adopted a koala, he bit me – and I remembered something important about myself
articles.trailText: As I watched the news about Australia’s devastating bushfires in 2020 I felt compelled to help. It was the start of a new relationship with nature, and a reminder of my childhood joie de vivre
articles.summary: As bushfires ravaged Australia in 2020, I knit koala mittens and joined the Australian Koala Foundation, 'adopting' Jarrah, a troubled but affectionate sanctuary koala near Perth. Two years later in WA, the half-asleep 21-hour-a-day sleeper bit me—reminding me he’s wild—and then permitted gentle shoulder strokes. His antics rekindled memories of my childhood koala toy and restored my long-lost joie de vivre. I learned koalas evolved 25m years ago, subsist on few eucalyptus species (‘koala’ means ‘no water’), and face endangerment from habitat loss despite 1937 protection. Inspired, I’ve adopted more species, logged 80 miles for the RSPCA, and volunteer for animal charities.

articles.title: ‘It is a dream come true!’ Meet Britain’s bus driver of the year – and six other unsung heroes
articles.trailText: From the top lollipop person to the most dedicated convenience store managers, we celebrate the winners of the year’s most unusual accolades
articles.summary: Seven UK workers earned unusual accolades. Michael Leech of Sowerby Bridge won UK Bus Driver of the Year after acing theory and precision parking tests and stopping for late runners. Scotland’s washroom technician Margaret Rutter clinched Loo of the Year for immaculate facilities. In Oxford, Hiten and Kinnari Patel’s Honey’s of the High was named Independent Convenience Store of the Year for warm, community-focused care. Gerald Gleeson of County Cork was Lollipop Person of the Year for high-fives and safe crossings. St John Burkett took Anorak of the Year for championing conkers, and Max Stanford topped the British Eating League devouring 25 bratwursts in five minutes.

articles.title: Zipora Whyman obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Creative cook and flower-arranger commended by floral competition judges for her ‘exquisite’ work
articles.summary: Zipora Whyman, born 1939 in Jerusalem to Kurdish Jewish immigrants from northern Iraq, died aged 86. Raised on kibbutzim Gan Shmuel and Sa’ar, she married British volunteer Edward Whyman in 1964 and lived in Ghana, Paris, Brittany, Jerusalem and England, where Edward worked as a nuclear physicist. A devoted mother, she taught Hebrew and literature to her children and became a celebrated cook of bespoke Middle Eastern–European dishes. In 2002 she trained in floristry, creating pressed-flower art and winning acclaim for her “exquisite” arrangements. Survived by husband Edward, sons Dan and the author, and grandson Joel.

articles.title: Alice Zaslavsky’s kataifi pie with feta, tomatoes and warm oregano honey – recipe
articles.trailText: In her quiche-pie hybrid, Alice Zaslavsky chooses kataifi for its exquisite crunch, eggs and feta for the filling, and a herby honey for the finish
articles.summary: Alice Zaslavsky’s picnic-ready quiche-pie hybrid uses 375g kataifi pastry layered in a 23cm springform pan, brushed with butter, to house a savory custard of 4 eggs, 280g yoghurt, 200g marinated feta, cherry tomatoes, garlic, onion and oregano. Half the pastry strands are snipped into the filling, then covered and topped with more kataifi before baking at 200°C for 45 mins. Finish: warm oregano-lemon honey with pistachios, plus rocket and feta salad, served warm or room temp.

articles.title: Two-sip martinis – and IV infusion drips: Soho House’s CEO on how wellness replaced hedonism
articles.trailText: It used to be all boozy lunches and late-night carousing. Now it’s hyperbaric chambers and longevity chat. Andrew Carnie, CEO of the private club, explains how life and trends have changed since the Covid era
articles.summary: Andrew Carnie, CEO of Soho House, marks the launch of its Manchester club—boasting the highest global waitlist—and illustrates the brand’s evolution from classic boozy hedonism to curated wellness. Framing its clubs as ‘third spaces’ that blend work and leisure, Soho House now features Reformer Pilates, HIIT, padel courts, contrast therapy tubs, IV infusion drips and hyperbaric oxygen sessions alongside two-sip cocktails and sustainable dining. Membership (from £1,200/yr) connects diverse creatives through mentorship schemes. After a 2021 IPO, Soho House went private in 2024 to refocus on member experience over rapid expansion.

articles.title: Barbara Cavanagh obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Dealer in antiquarian theatrical books and ephemera who had a deep knowledge of the arts
articles.summary: Barbara Cavanagh, 86, built a career as a self-taught antiquarian theatrical bookseller and ephemera specialist. Born in Swansea, she catalogued collections from Sergei Diaghilev’s costume designs to a 25,000-strong theatre programme archive. After roles at Swansea University and Ifan Kyrle Fletcher’s London bookshop, she and husband John founded Motley Books (1963), supplying manuscripts and ballet and opera materials to institutions. Renting Mottisfont Abbey (1972–93), she hosted a primary school, touring theatre productions and open-air revels. Later focused on ephemeral documents, she partnered with artist David Troostwyk. In Hastings from 2012, she remained active in local arts, recently selling an 1801 La Perouse prompt book. Survived by daughters Catherine, Olivia; granddaughter Erin; brother Peter.

articles.title: The one change that worked: I was trembling with anxiety when I found a fun, free way to get calm
articles.trailText: I can’t dance. Not even a little bit. But the terrible moves my friends mock are an antidote to the racing heart and quivering breath that arrive in my more anxious moments
articles.summary: After a stressful exchange with an ex left her heart racing and breath quivering, the author impulsively turned up a disco track on BBC Radio 6 Music and began dancing alone in her kitchen. Though rhythmless, moving to unfamiliar upbeat songs allowed her to transform anxious energy into laughter and calm. She prefers dancing solo to avoid judgement and finds the worse her moves, the more she laughs, deepening relief. Inspired by Grey’s Anatomy’s “dance it out” tradition, she now uses impromptu home dance sessions—choosing unknown tracks—to melt tension and restore her mood.

articles.title: The fascia secret: how does it affect your health – and should you loosen it up with a foam roller?
articles.trailText: Our muscles, bones and organs are held together by a network of tissue that influences our every move. Is there a way we can use it to our advantage?
articles.summary: Fascia, a continuous network of collagen-rich, water-laden connective tissue, envelops muscles, nerves, vessels and organs, acting as a sensory organ and biological spring that influences posture, proprioception and movement efficiency. Once discarded during dissections, it’s now touted by trainers for elasticity and self-myofascial release via foam rollers—but true benefit lies in fluid, varied movement, not “breaking up” fascia. Repetitive postures stiffen fascial lines; expanding your “circle of potential” through novel ranges (e.g., swimming, pilates, rock climbing or simple full-body stretches) hydrates, maintains suppleness and reduces tension more effectively than targeted rolling alone.

articles.title: ‘We thought the Rwanda scheme was the worst of it’: Enver Solomon on leading – and leaving – the Refugee Council
articles.trailText: It has been a difficult week for those working with refugees and migrants in the UK, after Labour announced controversial new plans. Sadly, Solomon is used to such turmoil. He discusses hostility, hope and asylum hotels
articles.summary: Enver Solomon, outgoing chief executive of the Refugee Council, condemns Labour’s new asylum measures—status revocations, 20-year citizenship delays, jewellery seizures and AI age checks—as a “grubby” low point, even worse than the Rwanda scheme. Drawing on experiences of far-right attacks on asylum hotels and his family’s multi-faith refugee roots, he warns the proposals will spawn costly bureaucracy, forced removals and UK-born children deported to unfamiliar countries. He calls instead to clear the asylum backlog, close expensive hotels and grant limited work rights to high-grant nations, insisting on hope and shared humanity.

articles.title: Which old Christmas traditions should be revived?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: In this instalment of the Guardian’s long-running Q&A column, editors ask readers to nominate ancient or nearly forgotten Christmas traditions — from wassailing apple orchards and lighting a communal Yule log to medieval mummers’ plays, twelve-day feasts with regional recipes, citrus and evergreen garlands, home blessing rituals and eco-friendly gift-swap ceremonies — that deserve revival. Readers can propose rituals, modern twists on carols or symbolic winter rites that foster community spirit and sustainable celebrations. A curated selection will be published next Sunday; email nq@theguardian.com or post in the comments.

articles.title: The kindness of strangers: I was wearing silly high heels - and someone saved me from falling down the stairs
articles.trailText: I was doing a good job of staying upright and dignified, until a surge of people rushed towards me
articles.summary: At 19, seeking a confidence boost after a break-up, the author wore a too-short skirt and dizzyingly high 13cm stilettos on a crowded Oxford train. Exiting at Oxford station, she tottered down steep stairs, clinging to the rail, until jostling commuters forced her aside. Losing footing, she braced for a catastrophic fall that would have felled everyone behind her—but a stranger seized her arm mid-air, steadied her, and guided her safely down. They vanished before she could thank them. The experience humbled her, ending her stint in absurd heels on public transport and restoring her faith in random acts of kindness.

articles.title: The loneliness fix: I wanted to find new friends in my 30s – and it was easier than I imagined
articles.trailText: It is said to be harder to make friends as you age. But I found that a mix of apps and other tools, as well as a happy attitude, led to a world of potential new pals
articles.summary: In her mid-30s, the author confronts the myth that adult friendship is doomed. When old pals marry, move or have kids, she turns to Bumble BFF, Timeleft dinner matches, SpareRoom viewings, local festivals and co-working spaces to meet peers. After 200-hour contact phases, she bonds with Rachel, Elvira and others over swimming, supper clubs and walks. Despite initial unease and ghosting, she finds that a proactive attitude, extroversion and emotional self-work make fostering new friendships easier than research suggests. Age isn’t the barrier – fear, anxiety and defeatism are.

articles.title: Readers reply: Do good fences really make good neighbours?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions. This week, the knotty issue of home boundaries, and what the saying was intended to mean
articles.summary: Guardian readers debate whether fences foster harmony or division, pointing to Robert Frost’s Mending Wall as an ironic celebration of the shared toil that bonds neighbours rather than isolates them. Comments highlight respect for personal and physical boundaries – from sun-trapping solar-panel fences and mature hedges to high walls and garden gates – as keys to privacy, curbside cooperation and occasional solidarity. Contributors recount spite fences, open-garden friendships, Netflix-inspired cautionary tales and local disputes, concluding that well-drawn borders can both protect and connect communities.

articles.title: Actor Dylan Llewellyn looks back: ‘I warned Mum that Big Boys was a bit raw. Thankfully she never commented on the glory hole scene’
articles.trailText: The Derry Girls star and his mother, Jackie, on an unfortunate vomiting incident, struggling at school and ‘bare bottom’ scenes
articles.summary: Dylan Llewellyn, born in 1992 and RADA graduate (2011), rose from early TV roles in Hollyoaks and Call the Midwife to acclaim as James in Derry Girls and Jack in Big Boys. He and his mother Jackie compete on Celebrity Race Across the World. Shy as a child—once vomiting on his mum—he struggled academically until More House gave him autism and dyslexia support. His comedy break in Derry Girls led to raw scenes in Big Boys, including a notorious glory hole moment. Jackie, who drove him daily to his special school and worried through his dyslexia and debut roles, praises his kindness and resilience.

articles.title: How to avoid buyer’s remorse this Black Friday
articles.trailText: A neuroeconomist’s advice for making better shopping decisions this season – plus, shopping experts on the best early steals
articles.summary: Neuroeconomist Dr. Uma R. Karmarkar offers four strategies to sidestep Black Friday buyer’s remorse: set clear spending limits, research true item prices (for example via Camelcamelcamel), create a focused wish list and avoid “ambition purchases” that fuel doubt. Trust your instincts to skip items you won’t actually use. Additionally, shopping experts have curated early steals worth buying now—from kitchenware and tween gifts to jigsaw puzzles and home appliances—so you can score genuine deals before peak sale days.

articles.title: Dining across the divide: ‘I don’t want to live in a white, Anglo-Saxon Protestant country with warm beer’
articles.trailText: They agree on green energy solutions but fail to see eye to eye on Islamophobia. Can a retiree and a graduate find common ground?
articles.summary: Retired underwriter Steve, 64, and psychology graduate Eva, 25, meet at a London restaurant to bridge generational and political divides. They find common ground on transitioning from oil to renewables—wind, hydro and cleaner air—and debate skilled immigration versus broad reductions. Steve explains Brexit’s impact on posted workers and low wages, while Eva challenges his views on immigration levels. Their friendly dinner—caprese salad, mushroom pasta and dessert—touches on Islamophobia, gentrification and enclaves, ending in mutual respect and a station hug.

articles.title: This is how we do it: ‘I’ll have to tell my wife what’s going on soon’
articles.trailText: Andy, who is in a sexless marriage, has become besotted with Rita – and their sexual chemistry is incredible. But how long can they go on like this?
articles.summary: Andy, 55, stuck in a decades-long sexless marriage, finds electrifying chemistry with Rita, 65, met via a ramblers’ club 18 months ago. Their playful, pressure-free sex—especially oral and light bondage—has awakened Andy, who can’t stay aroused after years of marital duty. Rita, divorced twice, embraces intimacy yet respects Andy’s marital bond, though limited to sporadic Tuesday lunches. Both ponder long-term commitment, weighing family loyalty (their daughter’s GCSEs) against the moral and logistical hurdles of turning this affair into something lasting.

articles.title: Five key findings from our investigation into the Free Birth Society
articles.trailText: Year-long investigation into multimillion-dollar business exposed serious concerns, from dangerous medical claims to FBS-linked stillbirths
articles.summary: The Free Birth Society, a North Carolina-based venture run by ex-doulas Emilee Saldaya and Yolande Norris-Clark, sells freebirth guides, memberships and online 'radical birth keeper' and midwifery courses, generating over $13m since 2018. A Guardian investigation found FBS promotes medically unsound advice - eg, zero infection risk cutting cords, newborn resuscitation delays - linked to 48 cases of stillbirths or neonatal harm worldwide, 18 directly tied to FBS guidance. Saldaya even texted mothers during emergencies, one resulting in stillbirth. Despite expert criticism and mounting deaths, FBS rebranded its midwifery school, added disclaimers, and defends its practices as disruptive.

articles.title: ‘Ignorant and life-threatening’: experts condemn Free Birth Society misinformation
articles.trailText: Professionals say claims about birth, including excessive bleeding, blue babies and placenta care, are dangerous
articles.summary: The Free Birth Society (FBS) is a multimillion-dollar unregulated home-birth movement led by two ex-doulas with no medical training, promoting unassisted deliveries, germ theory denial, antibiotic refusal, unmonitored preterm/post-term births, bizarre placenta and “cord hormone” remedies, and rejecting neonatal resuscitation. Experts link FBS guidance—dirty cord cutting; unskilled manual placenta removal; delayed breathing intervention—to maternal sepsis, infant hypoxia, neurological damage and deaths. Midwives and obstetricians condemn these claims as “ignorant and life-threatening.” A Guardian investigation ties FBS content to global maternal and infant harm; FBS dismisses criticism as propaganda. The Guardian’s “The Birth Keepers” podcast series launches in December.

articles.title: Being labelled a Highly Sensitive Person was validating and empowering – until it wasn’t | Miranda Luby
articles.trailText: An online personality quiz made me feel understood, but it also created a mental cage
articles.summary: Miranda Luby felt intense sensory experiences; an online quiz labeled her a Highly Sensitive Person (HSP), giving initial validation and community. But immersing in HSP content turned her trait into a restrictive identity, breeding anxiety: curated “must-dos” and threat-avoidance rituals made daily life feel like a minefield. A clinical psychologist warns self-diagnosis and hypervigilance can pathologize normal emotions. Luby realized her sensitivity is a malleable biological tendency, not a fixed pathology. By adopting grounding practices and cognitive retraining, she reclaimed agency over her attention, unsubscribed from the HSP newsletter and now experiences sensory depth without overwhelm, feeling free instead of defined by a label.

articles.title: The moment I knew: he presented me with my hearing aids like they were a little gift
articles.trailText: When Lynda Leigh and David started dating, his small, silent gesture spoke volumes about how much he cared.
articles.summary: In 2013, Canberra divorcee Lynda met accountant David over her taxes—and her hearing aids. His playful insistence on joining her audiologist visit, jokes about buying aids together and, most poignantly, presenting her hearing devices as a little gift, revealed his genuine care. He learned sign language, fueled deep conversations and courted her with candlelit dinners. They married in 2024, sharing ten years of devotion. A lifelong pilot, David returned to flying only to crash over the Snowy Mountains. He never came home, but Lynda treasures the silent moments when he invited her to hear—and be heard.

articles.title: ‘The flowing red saree on the bank of the Ganges was incredibly striking’: Divyanshu Verma’s best phone picture
articles.trailText: The Indian photographer captured a quiet moment at the popular Maha Kumbh Mela religious festival in Prayagraj
articles.summary: Divyanshu Verma, whose street-photography journey began in his hometown of Prayagraj, captured a vivid scene at the Sangam during the 12th Maha Kumbh Mela. Amid the vast spiritual gathering, he spotted two women drying a flowing red saree against the blue sky. Using only his phone’s natural light and later tweaking contrast, saturation and vibrancy, he accentuated sharp shadows and rich hues. Verma argues that mobile limitations foster creativity and that powerful storytelling relies more on presence, emotion and intention than on expensive equipment.

articles.title: ‘Superfluous consumerism’: adult Advent calendar trend alarms green groups
articles.trailText: Trend is adding to ‘waste crisis’ owing to individual packaging and potential for unwanted items, campaigners say
articles.summary: Environmental groups condemn the booming adult Advent calendar trend—ranging from Nivea’s £30 beauty countdown to Liberty’s £275 edition—as “superfluous consumerism” fueling packaging waste. Greenpeace’s Anna Diski warns most items go unwanted, while Everyday Plastic’s Daniel Webb calls it a “microcosm” of overproduction. Ipsos finds 70% of Britons buy Advent calendars—15% beauty editions—and early unboxing hype begins in September. Mintel and Lignin Industries experts note sharing strategies and upcoming extended producer responsibility rules will force brands to cut excess packaging.

articles.title: Which country is the fourth most successful in Olympic swimming? The Saturday quiz
articles.trailText: From pop stars in space to non-primates with fingerprints, test your knowledge with the Saturday quiz
articles.summary: This Saturday quiz tests readers across 15 diverse topics: 1) Lee Harvey Oswald’s last words; 2) the ampersand’s derivation; 3) Silbury Hill’s status; 4) the koala as the sole non-primate with fingerprints; 5) Katy Perry’s space trip; 6) Hotel Moskva on Stolichnaya bottles; 7) Ireland’s 1990s divorce repeal; 8) Hungary as the fourth-most-successful landlocked Olympic swimming nation. Linking rounds cover fictional innkeepers, succession wars, asteroid classes, bird flags, D-Day beach codenames, YouTube subscriber giants and team sizes denoted by Roman numerals.

articles.title: Who created the legend of Dracula and how do bees make honey? The kids’ quiz
articles.trailText: Five multiple-choice questions – set by children – to test your knowledge, and a chance to submit your own junior brainteasers for future quizzes
articles.summary: The Guardian’s ‘Kids’ Quiz’ presents five multiple-choice questions devised by children to challenge participants on topics including the origins of the Dracula myth and bees’ honey-making process. Curated by Molly Oldfield—host of the Everything Under the Sun podcast and author of its companion books (Everything Under the Sun, its Quiz Book, and All Around the World)—the quiz blends learning with play, inviting young readers to test their trivia skills and submit their own brainteasers for future editions.

articles.title: Blind date: ‘She did laugh a few times but I’m not sure if it was at me or with me’
articles.trailText: Henry, 28, a student, meets Sarah, 30, an operations manager
articles.summary: Henry, 28, a student, and Sarah, 30, an operations manager who has worked in an Australian abattoir, met at Namii in Manchester for a blind date. Both praised each other’s warmth, adventurous spirit and table manners—Henry dribbled prawn crackers, Sarah taught him chopsticks. They chatted about marathons, weddings, hero rats, DJ’ing and Dolly Alderton over spicy margaritas but felt no romantic spark. Henry rated it 7/10; Sarah 8/10. They shared another drink, parted as friends without a kiss, and joked they might cross paths at a race start line.

articles.title: Tim Dowling: my wife has always wanted to kick me out of book club. Now’s her chance
articles.trailText: We have difffering views on my contribution to our book club: I see myself as its beating heart; my wife says I’m an interloper
articles.summary: Tim Dowling recounts how he gate-crashed his wife’s all-female book club six years ago—first enticed by cheese, then declaring himself its “beating heart” despite her protests. After six years of perfect attendance, a scheduling conflict sidelines him, and the WhatsApp chat buzzes with inside jokes he can’t follow. His wife seizes the chance to oust him, but he orders the next book, reads it in 48 hours and shows up with homemade pudding. Amid teasing over who really founded the club, the group insists they still want him.

articles.title: Celebrity crib sheet: Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande are back on the red carpet – here are seven things you need to know
articles.trailText: As Wicked: For Good premieres in the UK, find out just how close its costars are, why so many of the cast are vegan and the truth about Grande’s move away from pop
articles.summary: Ahead of Wicked: For Good’s UK premiere, stars Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande reaffirmed their famously affectionate bond—matching tattoos, holding hands and even skipping press in solidarity—though Grande later tested positive for Covid. A Singapore fan’s red-carpet tackle prompted Erivo to shield Grande. Rumours of tension between Grande and co-star/partner Ethan Slater were quashed by insiders. The sequel’s animal-rights message has nudged co-stars like Jeff Goldblum toward veganism, while UK presales have doubled part one’s, spurring global tie-ins. Finally, Grande teases her upcoming Eternal Sunshine tour as a “last hurrah,” shifting focus to acting (Oscar buzz, Focker-in-Law) and nature hobbies.

articles.title: Be careful what you feed your tortoise | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Pets’ diets | Wales and England | The Covid report | Reaction to Boris Johnson | Good names
articles.summary: In a Guardian Brief Letters column, Martin Knight cautions tortoise owners against feeding fruit except sparingly and relying too heavily on dandelions, directing them to The Tortoise Table website for balanced dietary advice. Copland Smith clarifies that Wales, long a part of England when the Union Jack was created, explains the absence of Welsh emblems. Robert John decries the findings of the UK Covid response under Tory rule, and Robin Le Mare recalls the Arkell v Pressdram retort “Fuck off” in a jab at Boris Johnson. Terry Loane notes a surname coincidence with a late uncle bank manager, and the editors invite reader submissions for publication.

articles.title: A local’s guide to Queenstown and Arrowtown: ‘Like walking on to a film set’
articles.trailText: Ridiculously picturesque, with award-winning eateries and bars, the New Zealand South Island towns have more to offer than just adventure sports, restaurateur Penelope Johnson says
articles.summary: Penelope Johnson, local restaurateur and sommelier, spotlights Arrowtown’s gold‐rush charm and slow pace, and Queenstown’s lively food scene: The Cow’s classic menu, bar‐seated small plates at Rātā, tasting dinners at Amisfield, her Spanish‐inspired La Rumbla, and Wolf Coffee. Outdoor adventures range from Sawpit Gully walks to Remarkables peaks, Routeburn Track hikes and scenic TSS Earnslaw cruises. Evenings bring craft cocktails at Soda, self‐pour wine at The Winery, live gigs at Yonder and jam nights at Slow Cuts. Art galleries, the Lakes District Museum, Remarkables market, Glenorchy day‐trips and diverse stay options round out the guide.

articles.title: Zoe Terakes: ‘It’s a privilege to keep working while you’re transitioning. It’s also really challenging’
articles.trailText: After writing their first book, the actor talks about Greek mythology, a joyous Marvel universe experience, and going through puberty – twice – in public
articles.summary: At 25, non-binary Australian actor Zoe Terakes—best known for indie hit Talk To Me and Marvel’s Ironheart—has published Eros, a queer and erotic retelling of Greek myths rooted in their Cretan heritage. Having acted since 16 in Janet King, Wentworth and Nine Perfect Strangers, Terakes reflects on transitioning in public, the ‘privilege’ of steady work while undergoing second puberty on-screen, and finally affording top surgery thanks to MCU pay. They celebrate Ironheart’s inclusive set and the chance to play Jeri Blood without their trans identity defining the character.

articles.title: Experience: I found an old Rembrandt in a drawer
articles.trailText: I guessed it would be worth a couple of hundred pounds at most, but it was a preparatory print for his famous 1639 etching The Goldweigher
articles.summary: Author, daughter of artist-collector Alan Barlow, discovered an unframed 24×21cm etching labeled 'Rembrandt' hidden in her late father's Norfolk studio drawers while clearing the estate. Initially undervaluing it at ~£200 as a posthumous print, she took it to Cheffins where experts noted a Strasbourg Lily watermark and Rembrandt’s own chalk revisions—confirming it as a rare preparatory print for his 1639 Goldweigher etching. Now estimated at £10,000–£20,000 for a 3 December auction, the find offered emotional closure and will fund a contemporary artwork purchase.

articles.title: My ex is having an affair with another soccer mum and I feel complicit. Do I tell the husband or keep it quiet? | Leading questions
articles.trailText: They probably underestimate the cost to you of keeping this secret, writes Eleanor Gordon-Smith. Before you tell the husband, could you talk to your ex?
articles.summary: A reader’s ex-husband, two years after their divorce, is clandestinely pursuing a relationship with a mum on their 17-year-old son’s soccer team. Feeling complicit and anxious about the potential damage to both families and her son’s bond with his father, she wonders whether to inform the husband. Eleanor Gordon-Smith counsels weighing moral duty against unintended harm, and advises the reader to confront her ex: tell him he’s forced her into an intolerable secret, demand he either end the liaison, confess or face her disclosure.

articles.title: Is it weird facelifts are becoming normalized, or am I being too judgmental?
articles.trailText: It is a little weird that beauty culture is convincing people to surgically saw off their facial skin and sew it back on tighter
articles.summary: A 36-year-old reader feels pressured by today’s beauty culture to get a facelift she doesn’t want. Columnist Jessica DeFino explains this surge—17% more facelifts in the US since the pandemic, Google searches doubled, patients now in their mid-30s—through René Girard’s theory of mimetic desire. Cheaper, less-invasive techniques, buy-now-pay-later plans and celebrity transparency fuel “aesthetic inflation.” Yet rhytidectomy risks—hematoma, nerve damage, scarring, even death—and 50% rate of post-op depression or anxiety, plus $8,500–$200,000 costs, reinforce that a facelift doesn’t solve ageism, classism or real psychological needs. Ultimately, the strongest reason to refuse is simply, “You don’t want one.”

articles.title: ‘AI is scary territory’: art teachers – one 64, one 29 – on cuts, creativity and life in a career that’s under threat
articles.trailText: There are 27% fewer art teachers in England today than there were in 2011, and the proportion of students taking arts subjects has plummeted. Here’s what it’s like to work in a job that is essential and often perilously undervalued
articles.summary: Veteran art teacher Sue Cabourn (64) and early-career instructor Jasmine Pert (29) reflect on England’s 27% decline in state-school art teachers since 2011 and 48% drop in GCSE arts uptake since 2010. They recall pre-2010 era’s rich funding, technicians, 3D work and gallery trips; contrast it with current exam-driven, remote-learning constraints, heavy administrative load and student skill gaps post-Covid. While Pert embraces digital media, both warn AI threatens originality. They underscore art’s vital role in student wellbeing, social mobility and special needs support, urging sustained investment to preserve creativity.

articles.title: Tell us: what is the one thing that always leaves you feeling calm and positive?
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear about the simple ways you beat stress – perhaps a song that always calms you or a book you like to read
articles.summary: The Guardian’s Life & Style section asks readers to reveal the single activity, song, book or ritual that consistently helps them combat stress and fosters calm positivity. While experts recommend breathwork and mindfulness, this call-out seeks personal, practical tips—from a favourite playlist track to a go-to novel—that reliably lift mood and quiet racing thoughts. Readers are encouraged to share their unique stress-busters via an online form, with links provided for terms of service and privacy policy, to build a crowdsourced repertoire of everyday mood boosters.

articles.title: Tell us: have you ever received a terrible Secret Santa?
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear about your Secret Santa disasters
articles.summary: With the festive season looming, the Guardian’s Life & Style section invites readers to share terrifying Secret Santa tales—from thoughtless gag gifts and last-minute corner-shop buys to well-meaning jokes that flopped. Participants should recount the fixed budget, the random-name draw context, specifics of the ill-fated gift, recipient reactions and personal aftermath. Whether exchanged among colleagues, friends, or family, these anecdotes will spotlight how holiday cheer can go awry. Interested writers can submit stories via the online form and review the terms of service and privacy policy links provided.

articles.title: Thursday news quiz: TikTok horrors, hat-trick heroes and a rescued baby otter
articles.trailText: Test yourself on topical news trivia, pop culture and general knowledge every Thursday. How will you fare?
articles.summary: The Guardian’s Thursday Quiz No.224 delivers 15 questions mixing current affairs (viral TikTok ‘horror’ trends), sports milestones (recent hat-trick heroes), wildlife rescues (a baby otter), plus pop-culture nods. It playfully dismisses pedantic debates—like whether stage directions count as a play’s first line—while inviting readers to challenge any factual errors (with proof) in the comments. Participants can test their general knowledge, topical news awareness and cultural trivia, then share scores and feedback. For an extra music interlude, it even suggests watching Wet Leg’s new single “Mangetout.”

articles.title: Hold an ice cube – and shake like a dog: therapists on 16 simple, surprising ways to beat stress
articles.trailText: It can cause physiological and emotional problems, but none of us can avoid it entirely. Here are some of the best ways to react when stress hormones start coursing through your body ...
articles.summary: Therapists outline 16 accessible stress-busting techniques to regulate your nervous system when fight-or-flight kicks in. Recognise physical (headaches, high heart rate) and emotional (irritability, low mood) stress signals. In-the-moment tools include 4-7-8 breathwork, cognitive restructuring (“I’m having a thought that…”), cold exposure (ice cube, face splash, gradual cold wash) and shaking your body like a dog to discharge energy. Structure and routine help: make lists, prioritise sleep hygiene (7–9 hrs), balanced meals, limit screens (grayscale, no devices before bed). Connect socially or seek NHS/pro-bono therapy. Build resilience via mindfulness, creative hobbies, laughter and clear boundaries. These simple strategies, backed by integrative therapist Hannah Stebbings, Lauren Baird and Niro Feliciano, target both stressors and stress responses.

articles.title: Dog and cat abandonment soars in UK as owners struggle with cost of living
articles.trailText: RSPCA says pet abandonments in England and Wales rose by almost 25% in 2025 compared with 2024
articles.summary: RSPCA warns of a near 25% surge in dog, cat and other pet abandonments in England and Wales, with 24,270 cases reported by October 2025 versus 19,727 in 2024, driven by the cost-of-living crisis and rising food and vet bills. Scotland's SPCA reported a 20% rise in surrender calls, while the USPCA in Northern Ireland notes record kitten intakes. Startling incidents include terrier-cross pups dumped during Storm Claudia, a sick terrier left in a sports bag in London and Frenchie–chihuahua puppies in a bin bag. The RSPCA has set up pet food banks, a cost-saving hub and launched an appeal for frontline officers.

articles.title: Multiple children’s toys failed Choice’s button battery safety tests – so how can you make sure what you’re buying is safe?
articles.trailText: Seventeen out of 24 children’s toys from online retailers failed button battery safety tests, according to Choice – but there are ways to check whether toys at home are safe
articles.summary: Choice tested 24 children’s toys from Shein, AliExpress, eBay and Amazon, and found 17 breaching Australia’s mandatory button battery safety standards—batteries were accessible without tools, often lacking warnings; all four retailers removed the flagged items. The ACCC records three child fatalities since 2013 and an estimated 12 serious monthly injuries from ingested button cells. Standards introduced in 2020 (mandatory from 2022) require screw-secured compartments and safety labels. Choice urges parents to avoid cheap online marketplaces and button battery products, perform a simple drop test, check screw-fastened battery covers or opt for AA/AAA battery toys, while calling for stronger laws.

articles.title: Why are flights in the UK so often cheaper than taking the train?
articles.trailText: The environmental costs of flying are much higher, and the government subsidises rail travel, so what explains the baffling price difference when travelling domestically?
articles.summary: Despite government subsidies of £4.1bn and VAT-rate differences, domestic UK flights often undercut train fares: e.g. London–Edinburgh train £77 vs Ryanair flights from £15 (avg fare rises to €70/£62 with add-ons). Airlines dodge fuel VAT and deploy dynamic pricing and loss-leader £15 tickets to fill seats and upsell baggage, seats and priority boarding. Trains include free seat reservations, generous luggage and city-centre terminals. Factoring airport transfers and environmental costs (flights emit double CO2) narrows the gap.

articles.title: My ex shot me 10 times – and after the coma, I became an undercover cop
articles.trailText: When Katrina Brownlee tried to leave her fiance, he aimed a gun at her pregnant stomach. The 22-year-old wasn’t expected to survive, let alone walk again. But she soon began her fight for other victims of crime
articles.summary: Katrina Brownlee, shot ten times by her law-enforcement fiancé in 1993 while five months pregnant, survived a nine-day coma, paralysis and the loss of her unborn child. Despite his badge-wielding intimidation and his eight-to-15-year sentence, she pressed charges. In 2001 she joined the NYPD, excelled undercover, then founded mentoring programs for at-risk girls and now advocates tougher domestic violence laws: banning abusers from guns, creating conviction registries and mandatory offender rehabilitation, while urging police to adopt empathy and mandatory therapy.

articles.title: US leads the way to net zero Christmas
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Festive restrictions | Cool, dark places | Police and crime commissioners | Deliverance | Unfortunate street names
articles.summary: Guardian letters highlight Tyndall AFB’s Christmas décor curbs—decorations allowed only 30 days before Christmas through the third week of January, 6–11 pm—to cut energy use en route to net zero and suggest UK adoption. Contributors also share a Yorkshire manager’s winery-storage quip (“Huddersfield is a cool dark place”), debate abolishing UK police and crime commissioners over low voter awareness, question taxing the prayer “deliver us from evil,” and lament the absence of Trump Street or Farage Mews in local address lore.

articles.title: Silver splitters: why divorced women are so happy
articles.trailText: It’s not just Melinda French Gates. Many divorcees in their 40s to 60s are glad to be free – their male exes, less so
articles.summary: Midlife 'silver splitters'—women aged 45–65 such as Melinda French Gates and MacKenzie Scott—are reporting unprecedented happiness after divorce. Despite Bill Gates calling their split his biggest regret, a Survation poll of 2,000 women (220 divorced) finds 31% happier than ever, citing liberation, self-rediscovery and a fresh start. Jeff Bezos (55) and Scott (48) exemplify this among billionaires, yet the trend spans everyday women. Studies show ex-wives embrace wellbeing while ex-husbands often struggle. Behavioural scientist Paul Dolan notes that unmarried, childless women enjoy higher life satisfaction and longevity, suggesting later-life splits can spark renewal and a longer, happier life.

articles.title: Share your story of your most memorable pet
articles.trailText: Guardian column the Pet I’ll Never Forget is returning and we’d like to hear your stories about the amazing pets that you’ve loved
articles.summary: After a year-long hiatus and by popular demand, the Guardian is relaunching its Pet I’ll Never Forget column—celebrating magnificent creatures and mischievous critters who’ve left an indelible mark. Iconic contributors include Nelson, the unapologetic one-eyed cat; Verity, the kleptomaniac pug; Thumper, the frisky rabbit who surprised everyone with a litter; and Rambo, the Dexter-watching tarantula. We invite readers to submit memories of their own furry, scaly, slimy or feathered companions—past or present—and explain how they transformed your life via the online form (see terms and privacy policy).

articles.title: Houseplant hacks: can you use banana peel to shine your plants’ leaves?
articles.trailText: Rubbing the inside of the peel over leaves will leave a glossy sheen, but is it any more effective than a damp cloth?
articles.summary: DIY banana-peel polish: gardeners rub the inner side of a banana peel on leaves to harness peel’s potassium and natural oils, removing dust and producing an immediate glossy sheen. A trial on a rubber plant showed cleaner, brighter leaves but left sticky residue that attracted more dust within days, and banana fibers clung to textured foliage like calatheas. While fun for a one-off boost, the method’s stickiness makes it unsuitable for regular use. A soft damp cloth or microfibre duster is recommended for safe, dust-free leaf maintenance.

articles.title: Are you stuck in ordinary - but devastating - narcissism? There is a way out
articles.trailText: Meaningful therapy offers a path past our worst impulses. We should be fighting for it to be available for everyone
articles.summary: Moya Sarner, an NHS psychotherapist, warns that ordinary narcissism—a hollow, self-protective state—blocks meaningful relationships and drives harmful defences. She recounts her own analytic journey and patients’ breakthroughs, showing how psychodynamic therapy builds self-awareness, emotional tolerance and community belonging. Sarner challenges the notion that such work is only for the privileged, noting low-fee clinics and training schemes. She criticises decades of NHS cuts that have slashed free long-term therapy, and urges a public campaign to restore parity between mental and physical healthcare by making therapy accessible to all.

articles.title: The one change that worked: I had Sad and felt desperate – until a scientist gave me some priceless advice
articles.trailText: Since I was a teenager I had struggled in winter, experiencing excessive tiredness and low mood. A specific instruction lifted the gloom
articles.summary: Since her teens the author suffered seasonal affective disorder—exhaustion, low mood, carb cravings and breakdowns each winter. After interviewing a Finnish scientist, she adopted precise light therapy: sitting before a 10,000-lux lamp for up to an hour each morning before 10 am, five times a week, starting two weeks before symptoms usually appear. This routine reset her circadian rhythm—regulating hormones, appetite, immunity, alertness and sleep—lifting her mood, boosting energy and reviving her social life. Last winter she mostly felt like herself, embraced winter’s beauty and no longer dreads the dark.

articles.title: Is it true that … you burn more fat by working out on an empty stomach?
articles.trailText: There are modest benefits to exercising on an empty stomach, but it’s more important to burn more energy than you’re consuming
articles.summary: An overnight fast shifts fuel mix toward more fat and fewer carbs during exercise but doesn’t boost weight loss unless you maintain an overall energy deficit. Research finds fasted endurance workouts can modestly improve metabolic health—enhancing muscle adaptation and post-meal blood sugar control—while high-intensity training still relies on carbs. Ultimately, consistency matters more than meal timing: it’s about burning more calories than you consume. Beginners should start with 15–20 minutes fasted and stop if dizzy.

articles.title: The kindness of strangers: a woman cleaned up my toddler’s vomit – and paid for the paper towel
articles.trailText: I was sleep deprived and completely overwhelmed when she stepped in and took charge
articles.summary: With her husband away for work during the week, as a sleep-deprived solo parent of three-year-old twins—one recovering from a bug while the other fell ill—she walked to the chemist alone, carrying her sick child and guiding her healthy twin. When the latter vomited in a shopping mall, a passerby sprang into action, fetched and paid for paper towels, cleaned up, and offered support. This unexpected kindness a decade ago reassured her that strangers will step in and help overwhelmed parents in need.

articles.title: Ronni Ancona and Alistair McGowan look back: ‘We would have killed each other if we’d stayed as a couple. Instead, our friendship is eternal’
articles.trailText: The comedians on their Bafta-winning sketch show, the reason they split up – and why she reminds him of Diane Keaton
articles.summary: Impressionists Ronni Ancona and Alistair McGowan met on London’s 1990s comedy circuit, co-created the BAFTA-winning sketch show Big Impression (1999–2004) and combined Ancona’s surreal flair with McGowan’s wordplay. After a seven-year relationship ended in 1999, they channelled personal highs and lows into celebrity spoofs like Sven and Nancy. Despite early sexism on set and creative tensions, they forged an "eternal" friendship, still collaborating: Ancona co-hosts a new podcast, Hal & Ronni in Pieces, while McGowan pursues music and poetry.

articles.title: Readers reply: Why do we feel nostalgia?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: Readers suggest nostalgia arises as we idealize an often harsher past, forgetting anxieties and focusing on positive memories. It stems from personal yearning for innocence, unfulfilled desires and the comfort of formative years, while cultural myths about ‘simpler times’ amplify collective longing. A natural positivity bias filters out unpleasant details, making old songs, photos and stories seem golden. Nostalgia can boost wellbeing by reconnecting us to meaningful moments, but it also risks closing us off to the present. Politicians and culture warriors exploit nostalgic myths to polarize, weaponizing longing for eras few actually experienced.

articles.title: Do good fences really make good neighbours?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: In this instalment of The Guardian’s long-running ‘nq’ Q&A series, a reader questions the validity of the proverb “good fences make good neighbours,” which posits that firm boundaries strengthen community ties. Jamila’s query prompts fellow readers to contribute anecdotes, advice, and philosophical viewpoints on boundary-setting in everyday neighbourly interactions. The piece outlines the question, invites written responses via email or comments, and teases a curated selection of diverse perspectives to be published in next Sunday’s edition.

articles.title: Everything I wish I’d known before I decided to freeze my eggs at 36
articles.trailText: More and more people are turning to egg freezing to increase their chances of becoming a parent. Here’s what you need to know if you’re considering it – from the hidden costs to the chances of success
articles.summary: By 36, oocyte cryopreservation is a de facto first half of IVF: hormonal stimulation, sedation and freezing only guarantee options, not a live birth. UK egg-freezing cycles rose 170% (2019–23) after vitrification. You need clinic due diligence—compare live-birth per embryo rates, beware overselling—and budget £7–8k plus £500–1.5k meds. Expect 8–11 days of daily hormone injections, four ultrasounds, sedation recovery and skipped heavy exercise. Younger age boosts egg quality; multiple rounds may be needed (35–37 yo need ~15 eggs for 70% chance). Prioritise diet, sleep, support networks and realistic timelines.

articles.title: Dining across the divide: ‘We both came out thinking Zack Polanski is a breath of fresh air’
articles.trailText: They both liked the Greens’ Zack Polanski and disliked the tech oligarchs. But could they find common cause over the power of the unions?
articles.summary: Disillusioned with 50 years of Labour, 70-year-old Andrew, a retired acupuncturist, dines in Nottingham with 49-year-old Jonathan, a global tech programme manager who shifted from Conservative to Labour. Over fish and chips they unite against widening inequality, tech oligarch dominance and utility profiteering. Andrew champions unions as democratic safeguards; Jonathan backs worker representation but warns of overreach. Both see nationalisation without efficiency issues. They emerge agreeing Green MP Zack Polanski is a breath of fresh air on migration and economic reform. Though they didn’t swap numbers, they’d happily share a beer if they met again.

articles.title: This is how we do it: ‘I do get jealous and question whether I’m cut out for non-monogamy’
articles.trailText: Maya worried about entering into an open relationship with Ollie, but being honest with each other has deepened their relationship
articles.summary: Maya, 29, and Ollie, 35, navigate ethical non-monogamy with honesty and open communication. Initially insecure about Ollie’s experience and gender-fluid expression, Maya wrestles with jealousy and learned monogamous habits yet finds empowerment in a pleasure-driven sex life exploring her dominance. Ollie, recovering from past abuse, values Maya’s kindness, embraces vulnerability and cross-dressing, and trusts sexual openness but draws the line at deep emotional attachments. They’ve agreed on protection, transparency and no public intimacy, redefining intimacy beyond traditional monogamy.

articles.title: Celebrity crib sheet: Sydney Sweeney is everywhere – here are nine things you need to know about her
articles.trailText: A jeans ad made her notorious. Then she got cosy with Taylor Swift’s arch-nemesis. Time to get up to speed before the actor/model next hits the headlines …
articles.summary: Sydney Sweeney’s in the spotlight for nine reasons: her romance with Scooter Braun, Taylor Swift’s arch-nemesis, has reignited fan feuds; Jeff Bezos is allegedly grooming her as the next Bond girl via Amazon MGM backing; her Christy biopic bombed with a $1.3m US opening; her American Eagle jeans ad sparked accusations of promoting the male gaze and whiteness; she registered as a Republican in tax-friendly Florida; peers like Ruby Rose, SZA and Aimee Lou Wood have publicly derided her; she’s become a meme in online culture-war skirmishes; she relentlessly pursues brand partnerships—from lingerie to “morning wood” soap; and after four flops she’s hunting a career-saving success.

articles.title: ‘I try not to get him started on politics!’: power couples on rows, rules and who really does the housework
articles.trailText: As fewer people tie the knot, four well-known married couples share their secrets, from film director Bruce Robinson and artist Sophie Windham to writers Roxane Gay and Debbie Millman
articles.summary: Four veteran couples reveal rules for romance and housework. Bruce Robinson and painter Sophie Windham, married 42 years, work parallel creative schedules, she handles meals and childcare early on while he writes late; they escape to separate studios and dodge political rants. Authors Roxane Gay and designer-podcaster Debbie Millman, pandemic spouses, share travel planning (Gay arranges, Millman enforces) and equal finances. Musicians Laura and Jon McClure leverage family support and a traffic-light system for tension to balance touring and parenting. Novelists Greg and Kate Mosse co-manage multigenerational care, share writing feedback, and trivial chore conflicts fade over shared respect.

articles.title: My friend only ever wants to talk about herself. Should I cut her off? | Ask Annalisa Barbieri
articles.trailText: A face-to-face conversation telling her how her behaviour affects you would give you peace, even if she ignores you
articles.summary: The reader’s lifelong friend has consistently hijacked conversations, reverting every topic to herself and sidelining the reader’s insights. Despite admiration for her resilience through marital and professional setbacks, the reader feels trapped in an audience role. Psychotherapist Noel Bell advises a three-step conflict resolution: neutrally describe her behaviour, express its emotional impact, then jointly design new conversational norms. A private, face-to-face meeting is recommended to gauge body language and employ a silent listening exercise. Even if she resists, candid confrontation can grant the reader personal closure.

articles.title: The moment I knew: I felt a pang of fear – but I knew we were an unbeatable duo
articles.trailText: Kate Logan had heard about Tom Box before she met him. After spying him at a punk gig, she made a Dalek poster to capture his attention
articles.summary: Kate Logan first glimpsed Australian expat Tom Box in 2007 at a Wellington punk gig, then as a theatre set designer she lured him with a DIY “vague Dalek” poster after crafting podiums for a show. Banter-filled texts led to pool, pinball and roller-disco dates, and she left a rent-free squat for his flat. Despite fearing the end of her queer explorations, she felt they were destined. Over 18 years they’ve shared themed costume calendars, Tom’s native-bush restoration activism, cats, film-industry travel and home adventures.

articles.title: She was a prison officer. He was a convicted rapist. How did she fall for him?
articles.trailText: Cherrie-Ann Austin-Saddington was working in a men’s prison when she began a relationship with an inmate that would turn her, too, into a criminal. How do some of the most dangerous men in Britain get what they want – even behind bars?
articles.summary: Cherrie-Ann Austin-Saddington, a 26-year-old prison officer at HMP The Verne, began an illicit sexual relationship with convicted rapist Bradley Trengrove after he smuggled his mobile number to her in a magazine. Isolated by personal crises, she was groomed into texting him daily, smuggled in a phone stored as “Husband to Be,” and even attempted to inseminate herself with his sperm. Charged with misconduct in public office in May 2023, she pleaded guilty and received a suspended two-year sentence after a spinal stroke left her paralysed. Her case exposes systemic failures in staff recruitment, training and prison boundary controls amid a rising trend of officer–inmate relationships.

articles.title: ‘The speeding car created the perfect, eclectic scene’: Demétrio Jereissati’s best phone picture
articles.trailText: Initially drawn by the distinctive architecture, the Brazilian photographer struck lucky on a morning run in Cuba
articles.summary: Brazilian marathon runner and amateur photographer Demétrio Jereissati captured his favourite phone image during a 6am run along Havana’s Malecón in 2019.
