Drawn to a weathered building’s bold lines and glowing façade in the sunrise, he framed a young man in red shorts crossing the street. At the last moment a classic car the same shade of red sped into the scene, fusing architecture, local life and vintage motoring into an ‘eclectic’ vision of Cuba that still lingers in his memory.

articles.title: Why is there nothing Welsh on the union jack? The kids’ quiz
articles.trailText: Five multiple-choice questions – set by children – to test your knowledge, and a chance to submit your own junior brainteasers for future quizzes
articles.summary: This kids’ quiz, devised by children for Everything Under the Sun host Molly Oldfield, poses five multiple-choice questions about why Wales isn’t represented on the Union Jack. It explores the 1606 flag’s origins, when the Welsh lands were incorporated into the English crown rather than recognised separately, and contrasts England, Scotland and Ireland’s symbols. The article also encourages young readers to submit their own brainteasers for future quizzes and plugs Oldfield’s books and podcast series for curious minds.

articles.title: Which country music legend was almost killed by an ostrich? The Saturday quiz
articles.trailText: From Brick, Chancery and Hangar to Flat Holm, Lundy and The Wolves, test your knowledge with the Saturday quiz
articles.summary: Saturday quiz: 15 rapid-fire Q&A spanning music, religion, law, geography, energy, viticulture, sports, TV, architecture, chess, literature and cinema. Highlights: Johnny Cash’s near-fatal 1981 ostrich encounter; Sarah Mullally as the 106th Archbishop of Canterbury; the Althing parliament’s 930 Icelandic origins; ‘energy from waste’ acronym; Vesuvius’s Lacryma Christi vineyards; BBC’s Not Going Out sitcom; Taylor report’s push for all-seater stadiums; the queen’s Arabic vizier origin; London’s historic lanes; the Douro River’s transnational course; Nimrod in Bible, Elgar, aerospace and SAS lore; Bristol Channel islands; ancient Olympic events; literary spies from Fleming, Le Carré, Greene and Conrad; actresses who won Oscars in Woody Allen films.

articles.title: Blind date: ‘She friend-zoned me over text before the night was through’
articles.trailText: Alex, 31, an academic, meets Rachel, 28, a university caseworker
articles.summary: Alex, 31-year-old academic, and Rachel, 28-year-old university caseworker, meet at The Parlour in London’s Great Scotland Yard Hotel. He’s impressed by her curiosity and listening skills; she’s put at ease by his confidence and ‘flowing locks.’ Topics range from soul music and ACL injuries to academic misconduct, techno and star signs. Awkward moments include a waiter mishearing ‘Guardian’ and a puzzling wine-pour joke. They share free cocktails, hug but don’t kiss, and both friend-zone each other by text. Alex scores the evening 8/10, Rachel 7.5/10; both would meet again as friends.

articles.title: Tim Dowling: our lunch guests are always prompt … So where are they?
articles.trailText: The table is laid by 12.30pm and we’ve even ironed the napkins. At 1pm the meat is resting. At 1.30pm it’s time to make a phone call …
articles.summary: Tim Dowling recounts the chaos of hosting a carefully planned lunch for punctual friends who never arrive. After weeks of menu debate—pork with chickpeas, spinach, tomatoes—and last-minute pear tart and meat prep, the time passes with no sign of guests. Phone calls go to voicemail, worries mount, until a glance at past texts reveals he’d invited them to supper, not lunch. The couple devises a salvage plan: repurpose the roast into a stew, stash the tart, buy more wine, and laugh over their mix-up.

articles.title: Pity the fool who owns a pool. It’s like having a large, delicate, expensive pet | Andrew Herrick
articles.trailText: This back yard creature must be kept under constant chemical constraint, or it risks becoming more liability than asset
articles.summary: Bruce, one of 3.1m Aussie pool owners, faces winter pool wake-up dread as neglected chemistry turns water green. What began as idyllic backyard amenity has morphed into costly chore: weekly testing, expensive shock treatments and a cocktail of chemicals—chlorine, soda ash, acid, calcium increaser, algaecide, clarifier, phosphate remover, flocculant, stain and grease treatments—to avert algae blooms, equipment corrosion and health risks. Hiring professional service inflates bills; DIY upkeep demands hardware-store visits and specialist tools. Andrew Herrick likens pools to high-maintenance pets, warning that beneath blue waters lie relentless expense, time drains and liability.

articles.title: Tortoises need a varied diet, not just lettuce | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Rosemary A Fletcher-Jones offers advice on tortoises’ likes and dislikes in response to a column by Tim Dowling
articles.summary: Responding to Tim Dowling’s Saturday magazine column, Rosemary A Fletcher-Jones, a former zoo records keeper, warns that feeding tortoises only lettuce—virtually devoid of nutrients—causes malnutrition and death. She recalls many tortoises brought to the zoo suffering severe health problems, including organ failure. Drawing on 20 years’ experience and turtle club meetings, she urges owners to offer a varied diet of chopped vegetables (broccoli, spinach, carrots, courgettes), fruits (apple) and edible garden plants (dandelions). Observing which plants a tortoise nibbles in the garden reflects its wild habit of consuming diverse leaves and flowers, ensuring balanced nutrition and health.

articles.title: The grim conformism of pavement vigilantes | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Pedestrian etiquette | Guardian letters of old | Cool places | Marc with a C
articles.summary: Through fleeting eye contact and simultaneous sidestepping, pedestrians usually exchange smiles and “sorry”s—but Cameron Roh’s call for pavement vigilantes draws fire from Bob Caldwell of Northamptonshire, who warns it paves the way to an Orwellian dystopia of single-file conformity. Other readers weigh in: Margaret Martlew recalls a 1950 school-era letter urging bus-platform bins; Maggie D’Araujo riffs on sardines’ “keep in a cool place” label; Tim Davies shares his son Marc’s misprinted coffee cup after spelling “Marc with a C.”

articles.title: Question 1: Are phone cheats killing the pub quiz?
articles.trailText: Quizmasters are banning smart devices, using dedicated apps and finding plain old honesty can combat trivial offences
articles.summary: UK pub quizzes face a surge in smartphone and smartwatch cheats as teams discreetly consult devices under tables, prompting quizmasters from Manchester to Staffordshire to ban gadgets and deploy apps like SpeedQuizzing (with 10-second answer limits) to curb trivial offences. Some venues instead rely on peer policing and upfront honesty pledges. Originating in the 1970s and drawing 70% of Brits weekly, quiz culture now balances high-tech defences with traditional safeguards, as hosts insist firm rules and participant integrity remain key to preserving this national trivia pastime.

articles.title: Tell us your unusual name and how it has shaped your life
articles.trailText: We would like to hear about your name and how it affects people’s perceptions of you
articles.summary: Through this Life & Style feature, the Guardian invites readers with atypical names—such as Peach, Riot and Aquaman—to share firsthand accounts of how their monikers have shaped personal identity, social interactions, professional prospects and public perception, whether for good or ill. Contributors are encouraged to detail childhood misunderstandings, workplace bias or branding benefits tied to distinctive names. Stories may explore effects on self-esteem, first-impression bias, social media reactions and identity branding. Submissions should be made via the online form (with troubleshooting tips) and comply with the linked terms of service and privacy policy.

articles.title: Digested week: Ditching friends and family works wonders for managing Christmas | Lucy Mangan
articles.trailText: Plus, Kim Kardashian’s rage at psychics and Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor loses his titles but gains a hyphen
articles.summary: Lucy Mangan’s weekly digest kicks off with her tongue-in-cheek Christmas strategy—estrange friends and family to breeze through shopping in minutes and indulge in peppermint creams while researching pet gifts. Collins Dictionary’s word of the year is “vibe coding,” amid AI’s first avatar-sung hit and Musk’s Grok Imagine demo, plus dire 2.5°C warming forecasts. Kim Kardashian flunks the California bar, blames psychics. Prince Andrew grudgingly adopts “Mountbatten-Windsor.” The Royal Mint restores yellow gold £1 coins.

articles.title: ‘I found it 35 years later and dissolved into tears’: readers’ favourite photo booth moments
articles.trailText: As the photo booth turns 100, people share their best snapshots – including a private kiss and a chaotic proposal
articles.summary: To mark the 100th anniversary of Anatol Josepho’s coin-operated photomaton, Guardian readers shared nine favourite strips capturing milestone moments: a young couple’s awkward 1988 date leading to 37 years together; a mother’s airport selfie celebrating late-in-life parenthood; a surprise Berlin proposal amid analogue booth magic; a rediscovered seaside strip evoking a daughter’s bond and grief; a clandestine 1986 gay farewell under Section 28; a Paris flash catching a baby’s grin; wedding reception merriment preluding twins; and an Oregon father’s cancer-era keepsakes for his son. Each story underscores spontaneous intimacy, nostalgia, and the booth’s enduring charm.

articles.title: Experience: I played the trumpet for 25 hours straight
articles.trailText: I couldn’t repeat a song, and improvisation wasn’t allowed. I needed a very long set list.
articles.summary: Trumpet teacher Joshua, who picked up the instrument 15 years ago, spent two years preparing for a Guinness World Record attempt for the longest uninterrupted trumpet performance under strict rules: no song repeats, no improvisation, and only one five-minute break per hour. After a failed 24h46m first try in February 2024—disqualified for sipping water off-break—he succeeded on 9 May at Lagos’ Terra Kulture, playing classical, Afrobeat, jazz and pop for 25h30m straight. Supported by manager Dami and colleagues, he endured chapped lips, bleeding, exhaustion and cramped limbs. He now launches a Music Empowerment tour across Africa to promote perseverance, discipline and the value of music.

articles.title: Some days I am so homesick it hurts. What should I do? | Leading questions
articles.trailText: You’re desperate to go home, but there’s also a huge risk of idealising it, writes advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith. Start looking at the hard details outside the fantasy
articles.summary: An expatriate recovering from a serious illness contemplates returning home to be near family and old friends, despite a stable life, good job and home abroad. She experiences intense loneliness and repeated health setbacks, fearing she’s idealising an idyllic return. Advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith urges her to confront practical realities—financial costs, her husband’s career, visa and logistical hurdles—rather than remain paralyzed by inertia. By treating relocation as a serious option—researching work, housing and paperwork—she can provoke a joint decision and avoid silently defaulting to her current life, while weighing emotional costs against impermanent nostalgia.

articles.title: ‘You get more attention than you would choose’: how an unusual name can shape your life – for better or worse
articles.trailText: From Peach to Riot to Aquaman, anything goes now when it comes to kids’ names. There are even companies to help you pick one …
articles.summary: Rise in unique names has accelerated since 1983, with the UK registering over 64,000 distinct monikers in 2023. Celebrity choices—from Apple to X Æ A-12—fuel novel spellings and pop-culture references, prompting some governments to clamp down on “kirakira” names. Research links unusual names to identity, academic performance, career paths and nominative determinism, while hiring studies reveal ethnic and gender biases. An emerging naming industry charges $1,500–$30,000 for custom lists and branding. Meanwhile, one-in-six legal name changes aim for authenticity. The trend towards individuality shows no sign of slowing.

articles.title: You be the judge: should my boyfriend leave home comforts behind when we travel abroad?
articles.trailText: Jenna thinks Dave is not embracing the ‘living abroad’ spirit while living in Barcelona, while Dave wants to feel at home. Which one of them is being a pain in Spain?
articles.summary: Londoners Jenna and Dave spend winters in Barcelona but clash over Dave’s habit of covering worn furniture with British blankets and lugging Marmite, Mini Cheddars and teabags from home. Jenna urges him to embrace Catalan décor, cuisine and culture; Dave says familiar comforts help him feel grounded abroad. Guardian readers call for compromise—mixing old and new, shopping Spanish furniture locally—and a poll asks: should Dave try harder to blend in on his six-month stays?

articles.title: Thursday news quiz: hasty exits, horny bees and naked Nordics
articles.trailText: Test yourself on topical news trivia, pop culture and general knowledge every Thursday. How will you fare?
articles.summary: The Guardian’s Thursday News Quiz No 223 delivers 15 bite-sized questions on this week’s headlines and general knowledge—from hasty exits and horny bees to naked Nordics. Now published at 6:30 am (instead of its usual 11 am) while the author moonlights on the First Edition newsletter, it remains prize-free but invites reader comments and fact-check challenges. Test your pop-culture savvy and topical trivia know-how, then share your score in the comments.

articles.title: Tell us: were you sent away from the UK to attend school in another country?
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear from people who were sent abroad when they were children, and from parents who sent their children abroad, and why
articles.summary: Following a London High Court ruling that a British teenager, tricked by his parents into boarding school in Ghana over concerns about UK gang culture, must remain abroad until after his GCSEs, the Guardian invites adults who were sent overseas as children—and parents who made that choice—to share why they or their kids went abroad for schooling or to live with relatives, and how that experience affected them.

articles.title: No-toe area: why a barefoot living group has banned pictures of feet
articles.trailText: The UK’s biggest barefoot Facebook group has prohibited closeups after being targeted by foot fetishists
articles.summary: UK’s largest 'Barefoot Living' Facebook group (700+ members), a private community with vetted membership, has banned close-up foot photos after members, mainly women, received unsolicited fetish messages. Admin Sian Davis allows only full-length, location shots to maintain focus on barefoot benefits—muscle and tendon strengthening, posture improvement, sensory connection to nature—and to support those uneasy about feet. Member Ben notes admins swiftly review reports and profiles to exclude fetishists and preserve the group’s non-sexual ethos.

articles.title: Houseplant hacks: do humidifiers really help houseplants?
articles.trailText: Electric humidifiers aren’t essential for hardy species, but they deliver a steady mist and consistent results – at a price
articles.summary: Electric humidifiers deliver steady, measurable humidity boosts that exceed misting or pebble trays, reducing leaf dehydration and preventing crispy edges on tropical houseplants. In a two-week test with prayer plants, a tabletop unit eliminated new brown tips, produced glossier leaves and fresh growth. Downsides include frequent tank refills, regular cleaning to prevent mould, audible humming, electricity use, potential reliability issues in cheaper models and higher upfront costs for larger units. While hardy species like sansevierias or ZZ plants tolerate low humidity, more demanding varieties (calatheas, begonias) thrive with a dedicated humidifier.

articles.title: The perplexing rise of protein shakes: how a ‘meaty sludge’ became a billion-dollar industry
articles.trailText: In 1865, the first ever protein-based product consisted of ‘melted-down beef hides and carcasses’. Now, there are countless shakes on the market – including one by a Michelin-starred chef. Why is everyone drinking them?
articles.summary: The protein-shake market evolved from Justus von Liebig’s 1865 beef-hide extract to today’s £9–£11 luxury blends—like Michelin-starred chef Miller Prada’s Hermosa shake with saffron foam and spirulina. Viral Erewhon smoothies ($20+) and celeb-backed launches have fuelled social media hype, driving global protein-powder sales to $24.8 bn. A YouGov survey finds 25% of UK adults regularly sipping shakes, straining whey supplies and inflating prices. Historic milestones include Plasmon’s Greek-god branding, WWII ration tech, Hoffmann’s 1950s Super Hi-Protein, and protein-focused diets of the 1970s–2000s. Nutritionists urge 1–1.2 g/kg protein intake, whole-food first, caution against excess and unregulated ‘protein boost’ claims.

articles.title: ‘I opened up like a giant elevator’: the seven sly, savage stages of a £100,000 romance scam
articles.trailText: Last year, romance fraud rose 52% for over-55s in the UK. Victims often feel they’ve made a terrible mistake and are at fault – but really, they’ve been expertly groomed by criminals
articles.summary: This piece illustrates seven sly, savage stages—from love-bombing through trauma-bombing, sleep deprivation, hyper-intimacy and isolation, scripting daily life, dream-building to gaslighting—by which “Sam,” an online scammer, groomed Elizabeth, 67, into sending £100k over 2½ years under false crises. UK over-55s saw a 52% rise in romance fraud: victims, experts say, face coercive control akin to abuse, not mere deceit. Criminologist Dr Elisabeth Carter urges open discussion, reverse-image checks and bank transparency as safeguards. Scams end with threats and withdrawal of affection. Elizabeth’s sons intervened; some funds were refunded. Report such fraud to Action Fraud or Victim Support.

articles.title: Millennial dating involves a lot of sexy moves – so why does it so rarely lead to sex? | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Modern courtship entails a complex set of escalations, from texts to voice notes to photos, before everything fizzles out. Give me gen X messiness any day, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams explores how millennial dating hinges on a series of ambiguous escalations—texts, voice notes, benign still-life photos—meant to signal sexual intent yet rarely lead to sex. She recounts efficient park walks, marathon pub crawls, a trip to Spain and even underwear under the table, all ending in ‘nothing happened.’ Unlike Gen X’s direct bar approach, millennials rely on equivocal gestures (cheese-sandwich snaps, monologue voice notes) that generate confusion, wasted time and emotional limbo rather than real-world intimacy.

articles.title: I often shop online. Is there anything I can do about dodgy couriers?
articles.trailText: When a product isn’t delivered within a reasonable timeframe, it’s up to the retailer to provide a solution, writes Australian policy expert Kat George
articles.summary: Australian policy expert Kat George explains that under Australian consumer law, retailers bear primary responsibility for ensuring timely delivery, even with drop-shipping, but can shift blame to couriers for issues ‘beyond their control’ (e.g. failure to buzz). Consumers should first complain to the retailer in writing with evidence, then lodge a formal complaint with the courier. If unresolved, escalate to the Commonwealth Ombudsman (for Australia Post/StarTrack) or local consumer protection authority, and report systemic problems to the ACCC. For urgent items, consider in-store purchases.

articles.title: ‘It shows such a laziness’: why I refuse to date someone who uses ChatGPT
articles.trailText: It’s the ultimate ick: trying to form a deep, lasting connection with a person who outsources original thought
articles.summary: Author refuses to date anyone who uses ChatGPT, deeming AI-sourced ideas—from wedding venues to brunch spots—a sign of laziness, lack of originality and political apathy. After overhearing a groom plan his rehearsal dinner via ChatGPT, she adds ‘no AI users’ to her non-negotiables. Experts warn of ‘chatfishing’ on dating apps as AI reliance climbs; public figures like Guillermo del Toro and SZA denounce generative AI while platforms roll out opt-outs amid environmental and attention-span concerns. She even proclaims her stance on Hinge: no ChatGPT, no date.

articles.title: The one change that worked: I was burned out and stressed – then I found a steamy solution
articles.trailText: After a bereavement and world events left me struggling to cope, I tried meditation, yoga and therapy. But it was my local sauna that helped me find peace and purpose
articles.summary: A freelance journalist on the brink of burnout—squeezed by career uncertainty, family demands and recent bereavements—found unexpected relief at London’s Community Sauna Baths. After trying meditation, yoga and therapy, she discovered the sauna’s steamy sanctuary offered endorphin-fuelled stress relief, eased chronic muscle tension and improved flexibility. The ritual of heat, steam and brief cold plunges became a mindfulness practice that flushed away negative thoughts and restored emotional equilibrium. Regular visits now leave her rejuvenated, mentally clear and energised, with renewed vigour, community support and a stronger sense of purpose.

articles.title: Why do people love spicy food – even when it hurts to eat it?
articles.trailText: Tearing up, sweating and other bodily functions are all signs that the body is trying to expel spicy foods as quickly as possible. But there is a simple reason why some people enjoy those sensations
articles.summary: Capsaicin, the ‘hot’ compound in chilies, evolved to deter mammals by activating TRPV1 receptors on nociceptors, triggering pain responses—tearing, sweating, a runny nose—to expel irritants. Yet many enjoy that burn: genetic TRPV1 variants and gradual desensitization make the alarm signal feel safe, turning initial discomfort into a rewarding ‘benign masochism’ high as endorphins flood the system. Cultural and social rituals around spicy cuisine reinforce this thrill. Originating in 7000 BC Mesoamerica and booming in modern hot-sauce markets, spicy food blends biology, learned tolerance and communal enjoyment into a fiery culinary pleasure.

articles.title: Is it true that … the harder you work out, the more you sweat?
articles.trailText: Sweat levels can be misleading, and factors such as age, sex, humidity and even your clothes all make a difference
articles.summary: Sweating isn’t a reliable gauge of workout intensity, explains Adam Collins from the University of Bath. While increased exercise generates heat that triggers sweat for thermoregulation, environmental factors (temperature, humidity), clothing choice, and individual traits (fitness, age, sex, body size, climate acclimatisation) significantly affect sweat volume. Consequently, you can sweat profusely during light exercise in high humidity or barely at all during intense cold-weather workouts. Appearance can deceive: a drenched shirt doesn’t always equal maximum effort and minimal sweat doesn’t imply a light workout. Instead, monitor breathing rate, perceived exertion, or heart rate for effort. However, heavy sweating remains a useful dehydration warning—hydrate accordingly.

articles.title: A new start after 60: I found my feet in midlife, became a park ranger at 85 – and retired happily at 100
articles.trailText: At 104, Betty Reid Soskin has had the most extraordinary life, from protest singing to civil rights activism to meeting the Obamas. She reflects on what it takes to stay strong and keep going
articles.summary: Betty Reid Soskin, now 104, became the oldest full-time US national park ranger at 85 and retired at 100 after helping establish the Rosie the Riveter WWII Home Front National Historical Park. A civil rights activist, singer and entrepreneur, she ran one of California’s first Black record stores, supported the Black Panthers, served as a legislative aide and published her memoir Sign My Name to Freedom. Photographed by Annie Leibovitz, honored by Glamour and Barack Obama, she reflects on time’s shifting meaning, ongoing political chaos and her lifelong reinvention after losing key men in her life.

articles.title: No link between paracetamol in pregnancy and autism or ADHD in children, review finds
articles.trailText: Wide-ranging review finds no convincing connection after Trump said women should ‘fight like hell’ to avoid painkiller
articles.summary: An umbrella review published in the BMJ analysed nine systematic reviews covering 40 observational studies on prenatal paracetamol use and autism/ADHD risk. Researchers rated review quality as low to critically low and found any apparent association likely driven by family genetics, maternal health, or shared environmental factors. Sibling comparisons in one Swedish cohort nullified the link. Experts – including Prof Shakila Thangaratinam (University of Liverpool) and Prof Dimitrios Siassakos (UCL) – emphasize that paracetamol remains the safest fever/pain treatment in pregnancy, noting high fever poses greater fetal risk and ibuprofen is contraindicated.

articles.title: Why I won’t walk the way of a pavement vigilante | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Dr Tiziana Morosetti and Richard Dargavel respond to an article on walking etiquette
articles.summary: Dr Tiziana Morosetti and Richard Dargavel critique a Guardian article celebrating “pavement vigilante” Cameron Roh’s walking etiquette policing. Morosetti warns this brand of vigilantism risks sliding into fascism, noting demands to walk single-file or “go to a park” ignore hidden disabilities, childcare duties, stalking victims and parkless areas, and create anxiety around unexpected filming. Dargavel proposes importing the countryside code to cities: pedestrians face oncoming traffic at the kerbside to establish right of way when passing.

articles.title: Why do we feel nostalgia?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: In this installment of the Guardian’s readers-driven Q&A series, Jules from Fife asks why humans experience nostalgia and why certain cues—songs, scents, images—evoke it more strongly than others. The article invites scientific, psychological and philosophical explanations around memory, emotion and identity, examining brain mechanisms, cultural conditioning and the role of nostalgia in coping with change. This participatory feature, part of a long-running series on trivial flights of fancy to profound topics, will publish selected responses next Sunday.

articles.title: The kindness of strangers: a man I’d just met helped me land the job that changed my life
articles.trailText: Because he’d gone to the trouble of setting it up, I went to the interview – even though I didn’t have a visa
articles.summary: While backpacking in 1980s New York en route to Europe, a recent science graduate with electron-microscope experience met an Iraqi Columbia engineering student at International House. Despite lacking a US visa, the stranger arranged an interview with Columbia’s electron-microscope unit head. The interviewer immediately sponsored his visa and hired him. Over three years he earned free tuition to complete a master’s in international affairs, then landed a role in Zurich where he met his husband and started a family. That unprompted act of kindness set off a life-changing chain of events.

articles.title: She left her desk job and walked 3,541 miles from Mexico to Canada: ‘Give yourself permission’
articles.trailText: Jessica Guo hiked 30 miles a day, becoming the first woman to continuously hike two historic trails in a single season
articles.summary: Jessica Guo, a former consultant, quit her six-figure desk job to complete the first continuous thru-hike of both the 3,541-mile Continental Divide Trail and Canada’s Great Divide Trail in a single season. Over 152 days she averaged 48 km a day, gained 179,450 m of elevation and battled deserts, snowfields, mud, bears and mosquitoes. She documented her journey in daily videos to 50,000 followers, witnessed glacier retreat and sexism on trail, overcame post-hike depression and now dedicates herself to helping others set out—‘give yourself permission’.

articles.title: Readers reply: Who is the most evil villain in fiction?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: In the Guardian’s Readers Reply series, contributors debate the worst fictional human villains—from Shakespeare’s Iago, whose motiveless malignity traumatizes Othello, to Michael Dobbs’ Francis Urquhart, charming yet ice-cold behind a fourth-wall narration; Cormac McCarthy’s merciless Judge Holden; Melville’s obsessive Captain Ahab; Austen’s Aunt Norris; Dickens’ scheming Mr Tulkinghorn; Star Wars’ manipulative Emperor Palpatine; Thrones’ sadistic Joffrey Baratheon; Disney’s Cruella De Vil; Patrick Melrose’s abusive father; and iconic figures like Hannibal Lecter. Each epitomizes unbridled cruelty, calculated manipulation and the seductive allure of absolute power.

articles.title: Athlete Harry Aikines-Aryeetey looks back: ‘By five, all I wanted to be was a Gladiator’
articles.trailText: The Strictly contestant on his love of sprinting, the TV show that gave him his big break, and the family values that he still holds dear
articles.summary: British sprinter and TV star Harry Aikines-Aryeetey, born in London to Ghanaian immigrant parents, recalls childhood fueled by spinach-swilling Popeye, WWE and Gladiators dreams, and innate myostatin deficiency-driven strength. Spotted sprinting from a barking Labrador at 12, he became world youth 100/200m champion, Olympic and Commonwealth competitor, BBC Young Sports Personality and Nike-sponsored athlete while maintaining strict academics. After stress fractures and microaggressions about race and nationality, he reinvented himself as Nitro on Gladiators, a Strictly Come Dancing contender and broadcaster. Now a father, he credits family values, mental resilience and community bonds for his journey.

articles.title: Dining across the divide: ‘I was expecting some leftist, anti-capitalist, socialist Guardianista’
articles.trailText: They agreed on the importance of financial education, but how would a Trump supporter and a Green voter approach the issues of immigration and ICE?
articles.summary: In Bristol, American centrist Celestino, 55, and left-leaning Green voter Miles, 39, share a meal at The Saigon Kitchen. Celestino, a former paraglider in South Korea and naturalized US/UK citizen, voted Biden in 2020 and Trump in 2024; Miles, an accountant and part-owner of a Welsh sawmill, votes Green. They bond over the lack of financial education but clash on immigration: Celestino favors time-limited work visas and strict ICE enforcement, while Miles warns against racial profiling and questions Trump’s competence. Both enjoyed the debate and plan a second meetup.

articles.title: This is how we do it: ‘The sex is so good I walk around with a ridiculous smile on my face’
articles.trailText: Claudine and John both found a new lease of life on dating apps – and now put time aside to do things properly
articles.summary: After a 30-year marriage ended, 60-year-old Claudine and 62-year-old John rediscovered passion via dating apps. They met two years ago, hit it off instantly and enjoyed daily, pressure-free sex that revived their confidence and joy. Now cohabiting, they’ve reduced to weekly, unhurried sessions—often carving out midday hours when quick slots won’t do—ensuring deeper connection beyond occasional intimacy. Both praise improved communication, stamina and slower, vanilla lovemaking in later life, feeling energised by slow foreplay and genuine mutual desire.

articles.title: ‘You Britons go to the pub, we go to the swimming pool!’: the European health habits worth adopting
articles.trailText: Daily swims, power naps and five meals a day – not tips from the latest hit wellbeing podcast, but longstanding traditions that have kept generations healthy in Iceland, Ukraine, France and more …
articles.summary: In Iceland hundreds of geothermal outdoor pools fuel a swimming culture that blends fitness with community. Ukrainians practice lacto-fermentation of vegetables, dairy and fruit to preserve food and support gut health. The Swiss traditionally eat five punctual meals (zmorge to znacht) to stabilize energy and digestion. Dutch ‘uitwaaien’ brisk walks in wind clear the mind. In Denmark communal ‘fællesspisning’ reinforces social bonds over healthy, affordable meals. Spain’s siesta embraces short naps for alertness, while Germany’s light evening ‘Abendbrot’ aids sleep. France’s sophrology blends breathing, relaxation and visualization for stress relief. Italians enjoy post-meal passeggiata to boost digestion. Swedes limit sweets to Saturdays to promote moderation.

articles.title: The moment I knew: when we reunited in our 60s, it felt like coming home
articles.trailText: Lynne Besant met Paul as a teenager. After 40 years apart, she discovered she still had feelings for him.
articles.summary: Lynne Besant met Paul as a teenager in a 1960s Queensland caravan park and lost touch when her family moved. They reunited in Miami in 1970, traveled the US and UK, got engaged, but split due to her mother’s disapproval. Remaining lifelong friends, Paul married abroad and Lynne later divorced. In 2011, they reconnected in Perth, reignited their feelings, and married in 2015 to the tune of Moon River. Their reunion in their 60s felt, she says, like coming home.

articles.title: ‘Bike lanes are great – I hope these issues get resolved’: Rafael Escobedo de la Riva’s best phone picture
articles.trailText: On a street in Tenerife, an architect spotted a graphic composition - and evidence of drivers resisting change
articles.summary: Architect Rafael Escobedo de la Riva captured an arresting phone photo of newly installed red-and-white bike lanes in Santa Cruz de Tenerife colliding with cars as drivers resisted the change. The geometric arrangement reminded him of early-20th-century Russian constructivism, transcending the literal lighthouse motif others see. He champions the initiative’s health and environmental benefits, urging locals to embrace cycling infrastructure while inviting viewers to uncover hidden urban geometry in daily commutes. Months later, Escobedo de la Riva remains optimistic that practical challenges will be overcome and continues to find beauty in incidental urban compositions.

articles.title: How many trees a day do we cut down for paper? The kids’ quiz
articles.trailText: Five multiple-choice questions – set by children – to test your knowledge, and a chance to submit your own junior brainteasers for future quizzes ​
articles.summary: This children’s quiz features five multiple-choice questions set by kids to test eco- and general knowledge—from estimating how many trees are felled daily to produce paper to other environmental and science trivia. Hosted by Molly Oldfield of the Everything Under the Sun podcast, it engages young readers in sustainability facts and invites them to submit their own brainteasers for upcoming quizzes. The feature ties into Oldfield’s Everything Under the Sun book series, including her Quiz Book and new All Around the World edition, blending fun challenges with learning.

articles.title: What links Augusta Savage and WEB Du Bois? The Saturday quiz
articles.trailText: From a Celtic shield and a horned helmet to baloney, magenta and tarantula, test your knowledge with the Saturday quiz
articles.summary: This Saturday quiz features 15 eclectic questions covering Chaucer’s pilgrims, sumo weight divisions, the French Foreign Legion, the Bristol stool scale, England’s Ellie Kildunne Barbie doll, Munich’s Oktoberfest, Manchester vs Salford, Devo, fox species, consorts of King Georges, Italian eponyms like bologna and magenta, original ITV’s big four, animals drawing Greek and Norse chariots, artifacts dredged from the Thames, and central figures of the Harlem Renaissance, linking Augusta Savage and W.E.B. Du Bois.

articles.title: Blind date: ‘The most awkward moment? Trying to get the lighting right for our cute little selfie’
articles.trailText: Will, 33, a government officer (left), meets Fred, 29, a business analyst
articles.summary: Government officer Will, 33, and business analyst Fred, 29, met at Below Stone Nest in London. They clicked over West Country upbringings, books, opera and reality TV; Fred praised Will’s clever charm and table manners, Will lauded Fred’s relaxed energy, moustache and patience. After dinner they headed to a late bar for 00s hits, battled loud music and selfie-lighting woes, kissed and swapped numbers. Will rated the date 9/10, Fred 8/10, and both hope for a second meeting.

articles.title: Tim Dowling: life on the road was so much simpler than being at home
articles.trailText: On tour with the band there were no snapping tortoises, no dog kerfuffles and certainly no peeping scaffolders
articles.summary: After experiencing the orderly routine and friendly anonymity of life on tour—where baristas remembered his name and he avoided pet and home drama—Tim Dowling returns to a chaotic household north of Brighton. He juggles self-made lattes, a rampaging tortoise nipping his child’s toes, a dog that devours both lettuce and stuffed toys (even disembowelling Monkey), and scaffolders spying through windows. Between interrupted bath plans by a peeping scaffolder and family members glued to laptops, everyday chores feel like a minefield compared with the smooth rhythm of Travelodge mornings and coffee-shop camaraderie.

articles.title: I’m a food writer with a binge-eating disorder, and I’m learning to reject shame
articles.trailText: My job and my disordered eating have long fed each other. Talking publicly about my experience helps lift the veil of secrecy surrounding it
articles.summary: Food writer Sarah Cox chronicles her decades-long binge-eating disorder, juxtaposing public passion with private shame. Rooted in her Italian family’s food-centric culture, she recounts childhood chocolate binges, school-era yo-yo weight cycles, and lockdown-fueled binge takeaways. Diagnosis and treatment offered insight but kept her trapped in secrecy and self-loathing. Her breakthrough came after quitting her full-time food media job and spending three months rebuilding balanced habits—three meals, two snacks daily—while freelancing. Now she’s reclaiming joy in food writing, shedding shame by speaking out, and urging others to seek help from eating-disorder services such as Australia’s Butterfly Foundation.

articles.title: Feed them, love them and play them drum’n’bass: vets’ tips for keeping pets happy and healthy
articles.trailText: Dogs and cats aren’t always good at communicating to their humans what they want or need. Here, experts reveal 15 ways to make sure your furry friends are at their best
articles.summary: Vets share 15 essential tips to keep dogs and cats happy: research breeds and adopt from reputable shelters or breeders; feed a complete, balanced diet—avoid overfeeding, use puzzle feeders and limit treats; supplement with plain lean protein and vegetables but skip DIY meals; avoid toxic foods (grapes, chocolate, onions, xylitol); maintain dental health with brushing or chews; ensure daily exercise (at least one hour off-lead for dogs, interactive play and climbing for cats), ditch high-impact ball launchers; prepare for fireworks with drum’n’bass, comfy refuges and toys; groom appropriately; stock a pet first-aid kit; schedule annual vet checkups; and provide love and enrichment.

articles.title: Bob Brown: ‘Being an environmentalist is sensible. I like defying the growth mentality because it’s irrational’
articles.trailText: At 80 years old, the trailblazing environmentalist on the state of activism, optimism and why he is comfortable with the concept of his own ‘perpetual annihilation’
articles.summary: At 80, veteran Australian environmentalist and former politician Bob Brown reflects on mortality after surviving a pulmonary embolism, framing his life’s work in new book Defiance. He critiques growth-driven consumerism and shallow environmentalism, urging active nonviolent protest through his Bob Brown Foundation alongside policy change, and condemns governmental inaction under PM Albanese. He cites the “3.5% rule” for mass movements, celebrates Tasmania’s pro-Greens election surge, and reaffirms optimism in younger activists succeeding him.

articles.title: Had a bad year? Embrace ‘volunteer crops’, your garden’s gift to you
articles.trailText: If plants pop up where you weren’t expecting them, don’t pull them up – you never know what you might find
articles.summary: After a poor season, the author recommends embracing "volunteer crops"—self-seeded plants popping up unexpectedly after composting garden and kitchen waste—rather than weeding them out. This year’s volunteers produced cherry tomatoes despite scrawny stems; squash that enhanced pollinator visits; and raspberry canes ready for transplant to a fresh bed. Letting these unplanned plants grow not only salvaged yield but boosted garden biodiversity, attracting grasshoppers, gilded slow worms and ground bees. By accepting nature’s self-seeding, gardeners can transform setbacks into opportunities, filling vegetable patches with life and reframing cultivation failures as gifts.

articles.title: I seem to put out a strong ‘new-best-friend’ vibe, then I back off. Should I dial it down?
articles.trailText: Sometimes we feel threatened by bids for closeness, writes advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith. It can help to consider if you’re being true to yourself
articles.summary: A 70-year-old gay reader who once was quiet but now chatty finds herself giving off a 'new-best-friend' vibe—only to feel crowded and retreat—offending others. Advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith explains this flip-flop is common: we can unintentionally invite intimacy and recoil when past fears get triggered. While the other person’s hurt isn’t solely our fault, we owe it to prevent misunderstandings. Eleanor advises assessing whether back-off is a genuine boundary or a defensive pattern rooted in old memories; if authenticity guides your behaviour, it’s fine to stay chatty, but if recoil is unconscious, you might consider breaking the cycle.

articles.title: Share your favourite photo booth picture
articles.trailText: This year marks 100 years since the birth of the photo booth. We would like to see your favourite pictures
articles.summary: To mark the 100th anniversary of the photo booth, Guardian writers have revealed their most beloved photo booth images. Now the newsroom invites readers to share their own favourite snapshots—vintage or recent—alongside the personal stories behind them. Submit your images and anecdotes via the on-page form; troubleshooting and submission guidelines are available via provided links. All contributions are subject to the Guardian’s terms of service and privacy policy.

articles.title: Why are alcohol-free drinks so expensive? Some fake spirits cost over £25 a bottle!
articles.trailText: In this new series, our money and consumer editor considers the often perplexing reasons items cost what they do. As a new report suggests booze-free booze can cost 25% more than the alcoholic equivalent, what could possibly explain this?
articles.summary: Guardian money editor examines why alcohol-free drinks can cost as much or more than their alcoholic counterparts despite no duty. Sheffield Addictions Research Group data show no/low beer is 5% pricier in shops and 25% in pubs; cider 9–10% higher; 0% wine and some supermarket spirits can be cheaper. Premium branding, small-batch production, R&D, complex de-alcoholisation processes and pack-size promotions skew average prices. Brands like Pentire and Botivo charge £27–28 for artisanal spirits, reflecting lengthy distillation. Price barriers risk excluding lower-income consumers and widening alcohol-related health inequalities.

articles.title: Danes are Europe’s keenest nudists in principle and practice, survey suggests
articles.trailText: YouGov study of six countries finds those in Denmark most likely to approve of nudism and have been naked in public
articles.summary: YouGov’s poll of six Western European nations shows Danes are the most approving and active nudists: 87% deem naked in one’s garden acceptable, 35% on non-nudist beaches, 45% in open countryside and 64% skinny-dip in natural waters. More than 50% have been naked in at least one public setting, and 50% would shed clothing in public. By contrast, fewer than one-third of French, British or Italian respondents have done so. Germans remain top users of dedicated naturist sites (25%). Men and younger Danes are most enthusiastic.

articles.title: You be the judge: should my best friend stop calling me by a nickname?
articles.trailText: Priscilla knows that when Chioma calls her ‘Pris’ she means no harm – but finds it very annoying. You get to name the offending party
articles.summary: Priscilla, a writer, is frustrated that best friend Chioma shortens her name to “Pris,” “P.” or recently “Prissy,” triggering childhood trauma. Despite repeated requests to use “Priscilla,” Chioma insists nicknames denote affection and claims she hadn’t registered her friend’s preference. Priscilla cites subtle power dynamics and potential microaggression, especially when white acquaintance Mary joins in. Guardian readers largely side with Priscilla, emphasizing consent over intention. Poll: should Chioma drop the nicknames? Live event discussion on 26 November.

articles.title: Thursday news quiz: errant flamingos, bottled messages and space nonsense
articles.trailText: Test yourself on topical news trivia, pop culture and general knowledge every Thursday. How will you fare?
articles.summary: The Guardian’s 222nd Thursday news quiz serves up 15 questions blending recent headlines and trivia—from errant flamingos on the loose and vintage bottled messages to renewed moon-landing scepticism and the early invasion of Christmas adverts. This free-to-play test covers topical news, pop culture and general knowledge. Players can flag any genuine errors in the questions or answers in the comments, share their scores and enjoy a playful poke at holiday marketing. There’s no prize, but readers are invited to debate answers and even check out Ain’t Quite Right by Still Blank.

articles.title: Spot the difference: parents warned that fake Labubu dolls could contain lead and pose choking risk
articles.trailText: Australian consumer watchdog’s safety warning says counterfeit dolls – called Lafufus – can have wrong number of teeth and ears that are too wide
articles.summary: Australia’s ACCC warns that counterfeit Labubu dolls, dubbed 'Lafufu,' can pose choking hazards (detachable eyes, feet, hands; poor stitching) and may contain high lead levels. Fake dolls can have too many teeth or wide ears, and sell cheaply vs genuine Pop Mart Labubus (nine teeth, narrow ears; $32–$340). NSW Fair Trading urges buying from trusted sources. Lead exposure risks children’s development; parents should discard suspect toys and contact a poisons information centre or doctor.

articles.title: Are you a perfect modern gentleman? Not if you run in public or wear a tank top to the gym …
articles.trailText: According to Country Life magazine, today’s true gentleman will never expose his shoulders or modify restaurant orders, but can cook splendid omelettes
articles.summary: Country Life magazine’s 2025 guide to the modern gentleman updates its 2015 rules with 39 attributes—from fuss-free egg cookery (poached, scrambled omelettes) and waiter-name recall to timeless courtesy: no tank tops at the gym, no public running, pathologically punctual, never modifying orders. It blends efficiency, confidence and contrarian wit (Roger Moore is best 007), while affirming the enduring pillars of gentlemanliness—culinary basics and civility—wrapped in satire about decade-by-decade reinvention and future etiquette fears (AI-only chats, class-war scowls). It closes with the ultimate edict: never take anything too seriously, foreseeing future mandates like “no AI-only communication” or “smiling at strangers despite a global class war,” underscoring that basic courtesy and cooking eggs remain timeless.

articles.title: Tell us your experiences of living without a living room
articles.trailText: Living rooms are becoming less common, especially within rental properties
articles.summary: New research from SpareRoom shows nearly a third of rental listings now have no living room as landlords convert communal lounges into extra bedrooms. Some homeowners also forgo a separate lounge, choosing to socialise in the kitchen. The article calls for readers to share their experiences of living without a living room—how it reshapes household dynamics, space optimisation and cost savings, and whether the lack of a dedicated communal area undermines shared home experiences and social gatherings.

articles.title: The ‘pavement vigilante’: why Cameron Roh is naming and shaming bad walking etiquette
articles.trailText: He films people breaking his self-created ‘laws’ of street decorum and posts the videos online – with many viewers expressing their gratitude. So watch out if you’re rushing along on your phone or wheeling a small bag that could be carried ...
articles.summary: Cameron Roh, a 21-year-old pavement vigilante, roams Soho and US cities filming and rating pedestrians against his self-created ‘laws’ of street etiquette—speed, placement, footwork and phone use. He scores walkers out of ten for offences like sudden stops (“brake check”), zigzagging, ‘neck-gawping’ and ‘double wides’, while avoiding children, the elderly and less-able. His TikTok reels, now totalling 10m views, mix British humour with civil dissent, spotlighting growing smartphone distraction and car-centric city design in a bid to reclaim smoother urban walking.

articles.title: A moment that changed me: I thought I was a lesbian. David Bowie made me realise the truth
articles.trailText: When I went to the Bowie exhibition at the V&A, I hoped that by losing myself in his gender experimentation I might, in turn, stumble across a clue to my own identity ...
articles.summary: In 2011, two years before the V&A’s David Bowie Is exhibition opened, the author—recently divorced mother of four—came out as a lesbian and began questioning her gender identity. In 2013, a visit to the Bowie show in London and the ‘Boys Keep Swinging’ video prompted her to embrace a more masculine presentation, inspired by Bowie’s Berlin-era persona. After years of experimenting with style, a return to the Brooklyn exhibition in 2018 led her to realize she was a feminine man, prompting her to pursue medical transition. Her memoir Frighten the Horses chronicles this journey.

articles.title: A definitive list of what’s cool (and what’s not cool) | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to an article by Elle Hunt and share their own definitions of coolness
articles.summary: Readers build on Elle Hunt’s piece to define cool as authenticity, passion and minimalism—qualities exemplified by Miles Davis, Cate Blanchett, Billie Eilish, Lorde, Daniel Craig, Keanu Reeves, Lewis Hamilton, Colson Whitehead and Monty Don—while dismissing manufactured, manicured style. Genuine cool entails loving what you do, listening more, caring for others and speaking out against injustice; destroying the planet, killing civilians or upholding supremacy isn’t cool. Letters also praise cool jazz origins, kindness as the ultimate cool trait, Elvis’s enduring cool and the representation of Brown and Black people in media.

articles.title: Commonwealth Bank, Temu and HCF among those named at this year’s Shonky awards
articles.trailText: Choice’s annual list also includes the entire energy retail sector for allegedly hoodwinking customers with confusing prices
articles.summary: Choice’s 2025 Shonky awards named Commonwealth Bank for $270m in unfair fees on low-income customers after auto-fee-free accounts failed; CBA paused fees and made $25m in goodwill payments, but refunds remain unclear. Online retailer Temu was flagged when children’s battery-powered items failed safety tests and a child suffered burns from a noncompliant hoodie, with slow removal and vague safety promises. Health fund HCF closed its Premium Gold cover and replaced it with a 34.6% pricier Optimal Gold plan, sidestepping approvals. The entire energy retail sector was shamed for confusing “same name” tariffs that cost consumers up to $65m a year.

articles.title: ‘You definitely felt disposable’: models – one 27, one 62 – discuss Botox, weight loss, creativity and the threat of AI
articles.trailText: Modelling has changed hugely over the decades. Two models from different generations discuss the highs and lows of the industry, from the joy of travel and dressing up to predatory behaviour and physical pressures
articles.summary: NYC-based 27-year-old Danielle Mareka and London’s 62-year-old Dee O compare careers across four decades, highlighting an industry shift from agent-driven bookers to social-media self-promotion and the rise of AI models and GLP-1 weight-loss drugs. Both recount predatory pressures, disposability, and mental toll from strict body demands. They applaud the Fashion Workers Act and Model Alliance union for legal protections yet note persistent bias in size, age and race. They emphasize diversifying skills beyond modeling, navigating innovations like Botox and AI image rights, and modelling’s rewards of travel and creativity.

articles.title: Houseplant hacks: can a plastic bag revive a wilting fern?
articles.trailText: If the fronds have turned brown and crispy, all is not lost – this nifty, cost-free trick is surprisingly effective
articles.summary: Facing brown, crispy fern fronds? The article details a zero-cost plastic bag hack: situate the potted fern inside a clear, unsealed bag in bright, indirect light to create a humid “mini terrarium.” By slowing moisture loss and simulating rainforest conditions, evaporation is reduced and fresh fronds unfurl. A trial on a Boston fern yielded damp soil and green curls within 10 days, with fuller foliage by a month. Not guaranteed, and some fronds may die, but it’s one of the most effective DIY resuscitation tricks.

articles.title: Want to know everything? Perhaps it’s best if you don’t
articles.trailText: Exams, dating, parenting … whatever life throws our way, there will be uncertainty and surprises. The sooner we accept that, the happier we will be
articles.summary: Moya Sarner, an NHS psychotherapist, argues that the compulsion to ‘know everything’ stifles spontaneity, joy and insight. Drawing on John Keats’s notion of embracing ‘uncertainties, mysteries, doubts’, she shows how overplanning—even Googling new places or pre-judging relationships—robs us of discovery. Sarner recounts her agonising waits for exam results, pregnancy interventions, and divergent medical advice during her third trimester to illustrate how tolerating ambiguity is crucial. Through her psychotherapy training, she realised that knowingness was a defensive strategy. She concludes that cultivating the capacity to bear not-knowing enriches therapy, parenting and life itself.

articles.title: The one change that worked: I struggled with stress after work – until I made a discovery in my attic
articles.trailText: When my son was growing up, his school recorder was the bane of my life. Now it’s what I reach for at the end of a hard day, rather than a glass of wine
articles.summary: Feeling like a coiled spring after her laptop’s final click, a tone-deaf, impatient 51-year-old discovered her adult son’s childhood recorder and, using YouTube tutorials and a basic fingering chart, taught herself nursery rhymes and Ode to Joy. Dedicating 20 minutes each evening to this practice has replaced her glass of wine, eased her tension, slowed her breathing, boosted memory and auditory processing, and become an uplifting cognitive and emotional tonic—proof a simple musical ritual can transform end-of-day stress.

articles.title: Is it true that … consuming too much sugar can make you hyperactive?
articles.trailText: There is no solid scientific proof, but it would do us all good to cut back on sweet treats
articles.summary: Despite folklore that sweets make children hyperactive, no conclusive evidence supports sugar-induced overactivity, says Amanda Avery. Theories propose dopamine-driven reward spikes and reactive hypoglycaemia could trigger behavioural bursts, but clinical studies, especially outside ADHD diagnoses, show weak associations. Confounding factors like additives and caffeine in sugary drinks complicate results. Animal research hints early high-sugar diets might influence later activity, yet human data remain inconclusive. Regardless, average sugar consumption exceeds healthy limits, so reducing intake is advisable.

articles.title: Who is the most evil villain in fiction?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: Reader Carrie from London asks: of all the villains ever dreamed up in novels, films, stories, plays, poems, myths and songs, who is the single most evil fictional human antagonist? Excluding monsters and real-life figures, submissions (and new questions) can be posted in comments or emailed to nq@theguardian.com. A selection of responses will be featured in next Sunday’s issue of the long-running Q&A series—part of a weekly column inviting readers to tackle subjects from playful musings to philosophical inquiries.

articles.title: Readers reply: How much washing do our clothes really need?
articles.trailText: The long-running series in which readers answer other readers’ questions on subjects ranging from trivial flights of fancy to profound scientific and philosophical concepts
articles.summary: Readers advise washing clothes only when visibly soiled or smelly, using two simple rules. Underwear and socks demand frequent laundering; other items can be aired, spot-cleaned with soap, or washed at 30–40°C on eco or quick cycles. Modern EU-compliant machines use sensors and long lukewarm washes to optimize water and energy use, though a periodic hot cycle prevents mould in the drum. Towels may last a week if thoroughly dried but can mildew. Hand-washing stubborn stains under tap with bar soap is recommended. Some embrace minimal washing to reduce chores, others celebrate smart machines that adjust cycle length to load weight and soil level.

articles.title: Actor Alexandra Roach looks back: ‘I’m from a small town – when I snuck into a nightclub underage, 11 people told my dad’
articles.trailText: The Utopia and No Offence star on her love of electronic music, how she shakes off heavy roles, and channelling her righteous younger self
articles.summary: Alexandra Roach, from Ammanford, south Wales, wrote a campaigning letter at 12 asking for a Claire’s Accessories and began acting on the soap Pobol y Cwm. After training at RADA—where homesickness and a back injury tested her—she landed her first film role as young Margaret Thatcher in The Iron Lady. She’s since starred in Utopia, No Offence, Hunderby, Being Human and Amazon’s Lazarus. Roach recalls sneaking into a nightclub underage (11 people tattled to her rugby-coach dad), working in a jewellery shop and Tesco, and later rebuilding her confidence through a women’s DJ course. To shed heavy roles she uses somatic breathing, swims in the Avon and finds release dancing.

articles.title: The kindness of strangers: a surfer whose face I never saw saved me from drowning in a rip
articles.trailText: The water was past my knees, then it was past my chest, and then it dragged me under
articles.summary: In this first-person recollection, an 18-year-old visiting Maroochydore for summer misjudges a rip current, struggles as the water drags her under repeatedly, and grows exhausted trying to swim straight to shore. At her last gasp, a passing surfer asks, “Do you need a hand?” and pulls her onto his board, guiding her safely back to the beach. Now 74, she credits this anonymous rescuer with saving her life and reflects on the power of strangers’ kindness.

articles.title: Dining across the divide: ‘He looked like a typical Green voter – long hair, laid-back, that sort of thing’
articles.trailText: They locked horns on people crossing the Channel in small boats and cyclists using roads – did they find anything to agree on?
articles.summary: At a Milton Keynes Italian restaurant, 51-year-old centrist Philip, an unemployed ex-Labour/Conservative now leaning Reform, and 37-year-old left-progressive primary teacher Carl, ex-Green Labour voter, discuss Channel boat crossings—agree on safe legal routes but debate asylum abuse—and cyclists paying road tax. They share family refugee histories (Jewish Austrian, Ukrainian wartime labour), diverge on immigration enforcement and road charging, yet find common ground on improving quality of life and civil dialogue across political divides.

articles.title: Should I tell my husband I want to sell our brand-new dream home? | Ask Annalisa Barbieri
articles.trailText: Big building projects bring financial and emotional pressures, but it’s important to work out why it has triggered such strong feelings for you
articles.summary: After a year planning and months of building their dream home, a reader feels exhausted, financially overstretched and estranged by the house’s “vibe,” triggering anxiety and regret. Her husband remains optimistic but senses her distress. A psychotherapist advises exploring underlying triggers—childhood memories, unmet expectations—and urges honest communication about fears, financial strain and emotional burdens. Jointly discussing feelings and planning budgeting could ease her trauma and bridge their polarized reactions, transforming the house from a stressor into a shared home project.

articles.title: The moment I knew: I was riffling through my sudoku book when I saw a message on puzzle 239
articles.trailText: Actors Michael Wahr and Adinia Wirasti met on set in 2018. Less than a year later, his world stopped when he spotted a handwritten note.
articles.summary: Actors Michael Wahr and Adinia Wirasti met in 2018 on the HBO series Grisse in Indonesia, bonded over scripts and became friends. Months later, in Melbourne, Michael spotted Adinia’s handwritten “I love you” tucked into puzzle 239 of his sudoku book on New Year’s Day, marking their long-distance romance’s turning point. They navigated time zones, pandemic separations, FaceTime game nights, and roles on screen and stage before marrying in 2023. Now splitting life between Melbourne and Jakarta, they tour Bell Shakespeare’s Romeo & Juliet and maintain rituals like New Year’s Day Lord of the Rings marathons alongside their Australian shepherd, Batu.

articles.title: Rise in UK Thanksgivings driven by growing appetite for US foods, retailers say
articles.trailText: Growing UK American expat numbers also helping boost sales and bookings for a holiday once seen mainly in films
articles.summary: Thanksgiving celebrations in the UK are surging as Britons embrace US flavours and an expanding American expat community. Pipers Farm saw turkey and side sales jump 38% pre-holiday, while Ocado reports a 440% rise in Thanksgiving searches and 550% spike in pumpkin-spice. Herr’s buffalo curls (+410%) and Newman’s Own ranch (+202%) are top sellers. Mintel finds 67% of under-30s now keen on Southern dishes and 53% believe US holidays are mainstreaming. Restaurants like CUT at 45 Park Lane have doubled bookings, and Whole Foods UK’s Thanksgiving prep now rivals Christmas demand.

articles.title: ‘The rainbow of colours reminded me of my childhood’: Guillaume Lavrut’s best phone picture
articles.trailText: On holiday in his home town of Aurillac, the photographer was drawn to a pretty puddle of reflected umbrellas
articles.summary: Photographer Guillaume Lavrut visited his hometown Aurillac in the Auvergne mountains with his wife and three children. Known as Europe’s umbrella capital for its historic factory, Aurillac’s pedestrian streets led the family under a canopy of colorful umbrellas. After a rain shower, Lavrut paused to photograph their reflection in a puddle on his phone and enhanced the lighting with VSCO. He says the bright rainbow hues and perfect blue sky evoked childhood memories of puddle-jumping and offered a tranquil counterpoint to life in Paris and Nantes.

articles.title: What links Leonora Carrington, Steve McQueen and Leon Trotsky? The Saturday quiz
articles.trailText: From State of Play and The Hack to Tilly Norwood and The Velvet Sundown, test your knowledge with the Saturday quiz
articles.summary: Guardian’s Saturday quiz poses 15 eclectic questions: from naming Netflix’s DVD-origin, Hindu deity Ganesha, French #MeToo (#BalanceTonPorc), fig infestations, Japanese wordplay, Willy Wonka’s rivals, Katmai’s Fat Bear Week, Cornwall’s first dukedom, AI-generated actors and bands, Princess Royal title dates, global tridents, ‘Confessions’ authors, notable Mexicans who died in Mexico (Candy, Carrington, Feldman, McQueen, Trotsky), newspaper-based TV dramas, to claret-and-blue football grounds (London Stadium, Turf Moor, Villa Park).

articles.title: Why does whipped cream melt back into liquid? The kids’ quiz
articles.trailText: Five multiple-choice questions – set by children – to test your knowledge, and a chance to submit your own junior brainteasers for future quizzes
articles.summary: Five child-set multiple-choice questions quiz the science of everyday phenomena, including why whipped cream reverts to liquid. Hosted by Molly Oldfield on her Everything Under the Sun podcast, the quiz challenges your curiosity with junior brain-teasers and invites readers to submit their own puzzles for future editions. Fans can explore more answers in Oldfield’s books—Everything Under the Sun, Everything Under the Sun: Quiz Book and her newest title, Everything Under the Sun: All Around the World.

articles.title: Tim Dowling: disaster strikes at a gig – they laugh at my jokes
articles.trailText: Writing anecdotes that no one finds funny is not as easy as you may think
articles.summary: On his autumn band tour Tim Dowling relies on self-deprecating mug anecdotes to bridge songs. In Gloucester a veteran fan, Jane, boos him for retelling the story of Angela’s Scotland-to-Cambridge pilgrimage for a souvenir mug. In Plymouth another fan pitches an unbookable Monmouth venue, thwarted by its owner’s dislike. Then in Lyme Regis a deliberately awful joke unexpectedly lands, unnerving Tim, only to flop spectacularly the next night. He wrings comedy from the ensuing awkwardness while his guitarist hawks new mugs and hats during the interval.

articles.title: Blind date: ‘He said he didn’t feel great and left – I suspect it was because the conversation had run dry’
articles.trailText: Alexi, 34, an agent, meets Oisín, 30, an actor
articles.summary: Alexi, 34-year-old agent, and Oisín, 30-year-old actor, met in London W12’s Chet’s for a Guardian blind date. Despite good table manners and polite, fun personalities—Alexi calling Oisín “tall, sweet and smiley” (6.5/10) and Oisín finding Alexi “fun, intelligent and spontaneous” (8/10)—their conversation on work, travel, Primavera performances, coming-out and dating stories ran dry. They even requested the priciest bottle only to be turned down. Oisín left citing illness and jet-lag; neither felt a spark or kissed. Distance from their homes in Hackney also proved inconvenient. Both agreed on friendly vibes but wouldn’t pursue romance.

articles.title: Raw milk, tomahawk steak and a cuddly toy: could I handle Erling Haaland’s daily routine?
articles.trailText: The Manchester City striker recently shared some of the things he credits with his success. Could they bring me similar glory?
articles.summary: Manchester City striker Erling Haaland credits his fitness to a regimen of raw milk in coffee and straight, fried eggs with sourdough, daily assisted stretching, ice baths, red-light LED therapy from aestheticians and the comfort of a giant cuddly toy. A Guardian journalist attempted the routine: struggled with curdled raw milk, enjoyed a standard egg breakfast, experienced glowing results after LED facial therapy, but found a 770g tomahawk steak dinner overwhelming. The experiment revealed glimpses of Haaland’s disciplined habits and youthful recovery secrets—and one own goal courtesy of raw milk.

articles.title: The pain and pleasure of clearing a family home | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Parting with possessions and a Swedish death clean can be cathartic, says Lorrie Marchington
articles.summary: Lorrie Marchington, 76, writes about her ‘Swedish death clean’ after her husband’s death five years ago, as she sorts sentimental and valuable family heirlooms—old bottles, a 1945 contact lens, a grandfather clock, an Afghan wool blanket and waistcoat—seeking the perfect new owners. She gifts the clock to a friend with Parkinson’s, commissions a crafter to restore the blanket, and sells the waistcoat to an enthusiastic Vinted buyer. Through somatic therapy she’s learned to release possessions, finding catharsis, lightness and joy in passing them on.

articles.title: ‘Nature is abundant’: a local’s guide to Auckland/Tāmaki Makaurau
articles.trailText: New Zealand’s largest city is densely green and very pretty, says local art curator Nathan Pohio. It’s also packed with restaurants, small bars and galleries
articles.summary: Art curator Nathan Pohio’s insider guide to Auckland/Tāmaki Makaurau highlights its lush volcanic cones (Rangitoto, Maungakiekie), 14 easy climbs with panoramic city and harbour views, and coast-to-coast day trips from Takapuna sunrise to Muriwai sunset and Fairy Falls bushwalk. Culinary hotspots include Bao & Noodle’s spicy wontons, Nol Bu Ne bibimbap, Maison Vauron’s confit, Kompass Coffee salmon bagels and Parable House’s “dirty coffee.” For nightlife explore Ponsonby and K-Road’s Open Late, No 7 on Pitt, St Kevin’s Arcade and Whammy Bar. Cultural experiences range from Matariki at Bastion Point to gigs at The Powerstation. Stay at eco–friendly Hotel Britomart or Cordis.

articles.title: ‘It’s risky business emotionally’: the social shift towards open relationships
articles.trailText: With a rise in people opting for non-monogamy, experts suggest the idea of the traditional couple is radically changing
articles.summary: Therapists report growing interest in consensual non-monogamy—driven by celebrities, dating apps, social liberalisation and couples seeking sexual exploration or fixing issues post-affair. Experts warn open relationships demand ongoing communication, consent, trust and boundary reviews to navigate jealousy, insecurity and emotional trauma. They distinguish self-identified polyamory from heteronormative experimentation, noting some partners feel pressured. While openness can relieve monogamy's pressures amid declining marriage rates, practitioners caution it may mask unresolved conflicts, lack proven success traits and pose risks if feelings deepen or boundaries blur.

articles.title: Use firepits and fairy lights to make your Bonfire Night garden party go with a bang
articles.trailText: It may be the middle of autumn, but you can still throw a sparkling party in the garden
articles.summary: Drawing on village traditions, this guide covers prepping your garden for a Bonfire Night party: clear summer clutter but leave select perennials (nasturtiums, salvias, dahlias, asters) for interest and insect habitat; swap smoky bonfires for smokeless firepits; clean permanent seating and layer blankets and cushions; light the space with jam-jar candles and solar fairy lights (charge beforehand, remove to protect wires); cook baked potatoes and marshmallows in embers or your oven for a cosy autumn gathering.

articles.title: Experience: I dressed up as a superhero for Halloween – and then saved a man’s life
articles.trailText: The man was unconscious but there was no time to wake him, the smoke and flames were closing in
articles.summary: On Halloween night 2020 in Greenville, Ohio, a man dressed as Homelander left his family’s party after spotting a house ablaze. He instructed his wife to call 911, then sprinted in. His polyester cape snagged on a bannister but the Velcro gave way, and a neighbor caught it. Inside, amid heat and smoke, he found and cradled an unconscious intruder—who’d broken in—carrying him outside and reviving him with sternum rubs. The grateful trespasser later fled yet acknowledged owing his life. The rescuer joked about Homelander’s irony, retrieved his cape, returned to the party, and was later awarded a Carnegie medal and Ohio Fire Service Hall of Fame induction.

articles.title: A doctor’s bracing advice to new mums | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Celebrities’ bodies | Rachel Reeves | Income tax | Dogs on sofas
articles.summary: Four readers respond to recent opinion columns: Sarah Postins recalls her GP advising corsetry as the secret behind celebrities’ overnight postnatal figures; Chris Hudson asks Rachel Reeves to specify the income threshold separating “working people” from those with “broadest shoulders” ahead of the November budget; Michael Woodgate argues that Brexit-and-austerity-driven tax rises would hardly dent Labour’s electoral gains; and Melanie White laments the advertising trope of featuring a dog on every sofa rather than focusing on diverse home furnishings. The letters reflect concerns on celebrity culture, fiscal policy and advertising norms.

articles.title: How do I break up with a kind and generous man who leaves me feeling cold and irritated? | Leading questions
articles.trailText: If you want permission that it’s OK to hurt a good person: it is, writes advice columnist Eleanor Gordon-Smith . There is a life he could have without you
articles.summary: A 36-year-old immigrant woman has spent four years with a kind, generous man who offers stability but whose love of his hometown, pubs and football clashes with her dreams of world travel, van life, writing and solitude. Though he’s a good partner, their fundamentally different values leave her cold and irritated. Eleanor advises that ending the relationship is justified—not because he’s unworthy, but because their incompatibility already undermines both their happiness, and each deserves a partner aligned with their vision.

articles.title: Thursday news quiz: Dachshunds, Dave Ball, drag acts and data disasters
articles.trailText: Test yourself on topical news trivia, pop culture and general knowledge every Thursday. How will you fare?
articles.summary: The Guardian’s Thursday News Quiz No 221 marks ‘Willow week’ by starring its miniature dachshund mascot in 15 topical and general-knowledge questions spanning drag acts, data disasters and pop-culture nods like the late musician Dave Ball. Each question is paired with a charming photo of Willow, no prizes on offer but an invitation to share your score and spot any joke-based errors in the comments (with proof you’re not just fact-checking a gag). Plus, a nod to Dave Ball’s legacy with a Bedsitter watch suggestion.

articles.title: Are you in a community choir? We would like to hear from you
articles.trailText: Tell us about your experience of singing in a choir and how it has affected your wellbeing
articles.summary: An open invitation for community choir members to describe how singing together has influenced their wellbeing. The piece highlights research finding group singing eases postnatal depression symptoms for up to six months, and actor James Corden’s inspiration from his mother’s choir spurred his new comedy drama The Choir. It asks: what do you enjoy about group singing, any favourite songs or memorable performances? Share your story via the form.

articles.title: Can I learn to be cool – even though I am garrulous, swotty and wear no-show socks?
articles.trailText: An international study found cool people are extroverted, open, hedonistic, adventurous, autonomous and powerful. At best, I have three of these traits. Could I change that?
articles.summary: A self-described garrulous, risk-averse backpack-toting writer asks if they can acquire ‘cool’. Citing Todd Pezzuti’s Journal of Experimental Psychology study, cool people share six traits—extroversion, openness, hedonism, adventurousness, autonomy and power—yet must express them fittingly. Joel Dinerstein traces cool’s 1940s Black jazz origins and its postwar commodification, while the writer meets Cora Delaney, a London tastemaker whose agency brokers authenticity and edge, showing cool still hinges on individuality, hustle and cultural savvy.

articles.title: Should my boyfriend wear the clothes I buy for him?
articles.trailText: Bella says choosing outfits for Axel is her way of showing she cares. He wants to dress as he pleases and wonders if she’s trying to change him. You decide who the fashion victim is
articles.summary: This You Be the Judge column examines Bella’s habit of buying clothes for boyfriend Axel to show love and boost his confidence versus his desire for sartorial autonomy. When he doesn’t wear her gifts—jeans, Crocs—she feels hurt and he resents the pressure. Reader jurors agree gifts should honor recipients’ tastes and timing, not enforce change, and suggest shared experiences over wardrobe policing. An online poll asks whether Axel deserves a dressing down, highlighting the tension between generosity and personal agency in relationships.

articles.title: Shreks appeal: why gen Zs are settling for plainer dates
articles.trailText: Once you’ve had your heart broken a few times, there’s a lot to be said for a partner who’s kind and available – even if they’re a bit of an ogre
articles.summary: Shrekking is a Gen Z dating trend where singles date partners deemed less conventionally attractive to regain emotional control and avoid repeated heartbreak. Tinder’s Future of Dating report finds loyalty (79%), respect (78%) and open-mindedness (61%) outrank looks (56%) in partner priorities, suggesting a shift toward valuing authenticity over aesthetics. While critics like Jenna Bush Hager argue the term dehumanises and undermines genuine connection, advocates say redefining attractiveness fosters deeper bonds and challenges superficial dating norms.

articles.title: Alice Zaslavsky’s strawberry and stracciatella salad with orange dressing – recipe
